trans-unit.source: Monitor, diagnose, and troubleshoot Storage | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Monitor, diagnose, and troubleshoot Storage | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Use features such as storage analytics, client-side logging, and other third-party tools to identify, diagnose, and troubleshoot Azure Storage-related issues.
trans-unit.target: Use features such as storage analytics, client-side logging, and other third-party tools to identify, diagnose, and troubleshoot Azure Storage-related issues.

trans-unit.source: Monitor, diagnose, and troubleshoot Microsoft Azure Storage
trans-unit.target: Monitor, diagnose, and troubleshoot Microsoft Azure Storage

trans-unit.source: Diagnosing and troubleshooting issues in a distributed application hosted in a cloud environment can be more complex than in traditional environments.
trans-unit.target: Diagnosing and troubleshooting issues in a distributed application hosted in a cloud environment can be more complex than in traditional environments.

trans-unit.source: Applications can be deployed in a PaaS or IaaS infrastructure, on premises, on a mobile device, or in some combination of these.
trans-unit.target: Applications can be deployed in a PaaS or IaaS infrastructure, on premises, on a mobile device, or in some combination of these.

trans-unit.source: Typically, your application’s network traffic may traverse public and private networks and your application may use multiple storage technologies such as Microsoft Azure Storage Tables, Blobs, Queues, or Files in addition to other data stores such as relational and document databases.
trans-unit.target: Typically, your application’s network traffic may traverse public and private networks and your application may use multiple storage technologies such as Microsoft Azure Storage Tables, Blobs, Queues, or Files in addition to other data stores such as relational and document databases.

trans-unit.source: To manage such applications successfully you should monitor them proactively and understand how to diagnose and troubleshoot all aspects of them and their dependent technologies.
trans-unit.target: To manage such applications successfully you should monitor them proactively and understand how to diagnose and troubleshoot all aspects of them and their dependent technologies.

trans-unit.source: As a user of Azure Storage services, you should continuously monitor the Storage services your application uses for any unexpected changes in behavior (such as slower than usual response times), and use logging to collect more detailed data and to analyze a problem in depth.
trans-unit.target: As a user of Azure Storage services, you should continuously monitor the Storage services your application uses for any unexpected changes in behavior (such as slower than usual response times), and use logging to collect more detailed data and to analyze a problem in depth.

trans-unit.source: The diagnostics information you obtain from both monitoring and logging will help you to determine the root cause of the issue your application encountered.
trans-unit.target: The diagnostics information you obtain from both monitoring and logging will help you to determine the root cause of the issue your application encountered.

trans-unit.source: Then you can troubleshoot the issue and determine the appropriate steps you can take to remediate it.
trans-unit.target: Then you can troubleshoot the issue and determine the appropriate steps you can take to remediate it.

trans-unit.source: Azure Storage is a core Azure service, and forms an important part of the majority of solutions that customers deploy to the Azure infrastructure.
trans-unit.target: Azure Storage is a core Azure service, and forms an important part of the majority of solutions that customers deploy to the Azure infrastructure.

trans-unit.source: Azure Storage includes capabilities to simplify monitoring, diagnosing, and troubleshooting storage issues in your cloud-based applications.
trans-unit.target: Azure Storage includes capabilities to simplify monitoring, diagnosing, and troubleshooting storage issues in your cloud-based applications.

trans-unit.source: For a hands-on guide to end-to-end troubleshooting in Azure Storage applications, see [End-to-End Troubleshooting using Azure Storage Metrics and Logging, AzCopy, and Message Analyzer](../storage-e2e-troubleshooting/).
trans-unit.target: For a hands-on guide to end-to-end troubleshooting in Azure Storage applications, see [End-to-End Troubleshooting using Azure Storage Metrics and Logging, AzCopy, and Message Analyzer](../storage-e2e-troubleshooting/).

trans-unit.source: Introduction
trans-unit.target: Introduction

trans-unit.source: This guide shows you how to use features such as Azure Storage Analytics, client-side logging in the Azure Storage Client Library, and other third-party tools to identify, diagnose, and troubleshoot Azure Storage related issues.
trans-unit.target: This guide shows you how to use features such as Azure Storage Analytics, client-side logging in the Azure Storage Client Library, and other third-party tools to identify, diagnose, and troubleshoot Azure Storage related issues.

trans-unit.source: Figure 1 Monitoring, Diagnostics, and Troubleshooting
trans-unit.target: Figure 1 Monitoring, Diagnostics, and Troubleshooting

trans-unit.source: This guide is intended to be read primarily by developers of online services that use Azure Storage Services and IT Pros responsible for managing such online services.
trans-unit.target: This guide is intended to be read primarily by developers of online services that use Azure Storage Services and IT Pros responsible for managing such online services.

trans-unit.source: The goals of this guide are:
trans-unit.target: The goals of this guide are:

trans-unit.source: To help you maintain the health and performance of your Azure Storage accounts.
trans-unit.target: To help you maintain the health and performance of your Azure Storage accounts.

trans-unit.source: To provide you with the necessary processes and tools to help you decide if an issue or problem in an application relates to Azure Storage.
trans-unit.target: To provide you with the necessary processes and tools to help you decide if an issue or problem in an application relates to Azure Storage.

trans-unit.source: To provide you with actionable guidance for resolving problems related to Azure Storage.
trans-unit.target: To provide you with actionable guidance for resolving problems related to Azure Storage.

trans-unit.source: How this guide is organized
trans-unit.target: How this guide is organized

trans-unit.source: The section "[Monitoring your storage service]" describes how to monitor the health and performance of your Azure Storage services using Azure Storage Analytics Metrics (Storage Metrics).
trans-unit.target: The section "[Monitoring your storage service]" describes how to monitor the health and performance of your Azure Storage services using Azure Storage Analytics Metrics (Storage Metrics).

trans-unit.source: The section "[Diagnosing storage issues]" describes how to diagnose issues using Azure Storage Analytics Logging (Storage Logging).
trans-unit.target: The section "[Diagnosing storage issues]" describes how to diagnose issues using Azure Storage Analytics Logging (Storage Logging).

trans-unit.source: It also describes how to enable client-side logging using the facilities in one of the client libraries such as the Storage Client Library for .NET or the Azure SDK for Java.
trans-unit.target: It also describes how to enable client-side logging using the facilities in one of the client libraries such as the Storage Client Library for .NET or the Azure SDK for Java.

trans-unit.source: The section "[End-to-end tracing]" describes how you can correlate the information contained in various log files and metrics data.
trans-unit.target: The section "[End-to-end tracing]" describes how you can correlate the information contained in various log files and metrics data.

trans-unit.source: The section "[Troubleshooting guidance]" provides troubleshooting guidance for some of the common storage-related issues you might encounter.
trans-unit.target: The section "[Troubleshooting guidance]" provides troubleshooting guidance for some of the common storage-related issues you might encounter.

trans-unit.source: The "[Appendices]" include information about using other tools such as Wireshark and Netmon for analyzing network packet data, Fiddler for analyzing HTTP/HTTPS messages, and Microsoft Message Analyzer for correlating log data.
trans-unit.target: The "[Appendices]" include information about using other tools such as Wireshark and Netmon for analyzing network packet data, Fiddler for analyzing HTTP/HTTPS messages, and Microsoft Message Analyzer for correlating log data.

trans-unit.source: Monitoring your storage service
trans-unit.target: Monitoring your storage service

trans-unit.source: If you are familiar with Windows performance monitoring, you can think of Storage Metrics as being an Azure Storage equivalent of Windows Performance Monitor counters.
trans-unit.target: If you are familiar with Windows performance monitoring, you can think of Storage Metrics as being an Azure Storage equivalent of Windows Performance Monitor counters.

trans-unit.source: In Storage Metrics you will find a comprehensive set of metrics (counters in Windows Performance Monitor terminology) such as service availability, total number of requests to service, or percentage of successful requests to service (for a full list of the available metrics, see Storage Analytics Metrics Table Schema on MSDN).
trans-unit.target: In Storage Metrics you will find a comprehensive set of metrics (counters in Windows Performance Monitor terminology) such as service availability, total number of requests to service, or percentage of successful requests to service (for a full list of the available metrics, see Storage Analytics Metrics Table Schema on MSDN).

trans-unit.source: You can specify whether you want the storage service to collect and aggregate metrics every hour or every minute.
trans-unit.target: You can specify whether you want the storage service to collect and aggregate metrics every hour or every minute.

trans-unit.source: For more information about how to enable metrics and monitor your storage accounts, see Enabling storage metrics on MSDN.
trans-unit.target: For more information about how to enable metrics and monitor your storage accounts, see Enabling storage metrics on MSDN.

trans-unit.source: You can choose which hourly metrics you want to display in the Azure portal and configure rules that notify administrators by email whenever an hourly metric exceeds a particular threshold (for more information, see the page How to: Receive Alert Notifications and Manage Alert Rules in Azure).
trans-unit.target: You can choose which hourly metrics you want to display in the Azure portal and configure rules that notify administrators by email whenever an hourly metric exceeds a particular threshold (for more information, see the page How to: Receive Alert Notifications and Manage Alert Rules in Azure).

trans-unit.source: The storage service collects metrics using a best effort, but may not record every storage operation.
trans-unit.target: The storage service collects metrics using a best effort, but may not record every storage operation.

trans-unit.source: Figure 2 below shows the Monitor page in the portal where you can view metrics such as availability, total requests, and average latency numbers for a storage account.
trans-unit.target: Figure 2 below shows the Monitor page in the portal where you can view metrics such as availability, total requests, and average latency numbers for a storage account.

trans-unit.source: A notification rule has also been set up to alert an administrator if availability drops below a certain level.
trans-unit.target: A notification rule has also been set up to alert an administrator if availability drops below a certain level.

trans-unit.source: From viewing this data, one possible area for investigation is the table service success percentage being below 100% (for more information, see the section "[Metrics show low PercentSuccess or analytics log entries have operations with transaction status of ClientOtherErrors]").
trans-unit.target: From viewing this data, one possible area for investigation is the table service success percentage being below 100% (for more information, see the section "[Metrics show low PercentSuccess or analytics log entries have operations with transaction status of ClientOtherErrors]").

trans-unit.source: Figure 2 Viewing storage metrics in the portal
trans-unit.target: Figure 2 Viewing storage metrics in the portal

trans-unit.source: You should continuously monitor your Azure applications to ensure they are healthy and performing as expected by:
trans-unit.target: You should continuously monitor your Azure applications to ensure they are healthy and performing as expected by:

trans-unit.source: Establishing some baseline metrics for application that will enable you to compare current data and identify any significant changes in the behavior of Azure storage and your application.
trans-unit.target: Establishing some baseline metrics for application that will enable you to compare current data and identify any significant changes in the behavior of Azure storage and your application.

trans-unit.source: The values of your baseline metrics will, in many cases, be application specific and you should establish them when you are performance testing your application.
trans-unit.target: The values of your baseline metrics will, in many cases, be application specific and you should establish them when you are performance testing your application.

trans-unit.source: Recording minute metrics and using them to monitor actively for unexpected errors and anomalies such as spikes in error counts or request rates.
trans-unit.target: Recording minute metrics and using them to monitor actively for unexpected errors and anomalies such as spikes in error counts or request rates.

trans-unit.source: Recording hourly metrics and using them to monitor average values such as average error counts and request rates.
trans-unit.target: Recording hourly metrics and using them to monitor average values such as average error counts and request rates.

trans-unit.source: Investigating potential issues using diagnostics tools as discussed later in the section "[Diagnosing storage issues]."
trans-unit.target: Investigating potential issues using diagnostics tools as discussed later in the section "[Diagnosing storage issues]."

trans-unit.source: The charts in Figure 3 below illustrate how the averaging that occurs for hourly metrics can hide spikes in activity.
trans-unit.target: The charts in Figure 3 below illustrate how the averaging that occurs for hourly metrics can hide spikes in activity.

trans-unit.source: The hourly metrics appear to show a steady rate of requests, while the minute metrics reveal the fluctuations that are really taking place.
trans-unit.target: The hourly metrics appear to show a steady rate of requests, while the minute metrics reveal the fluctuations that are really taking place.

trans-unit.source: The remainder of this section describes what metrics you should monitor and why.
trans-unit.target: The remainder of this section describes what metrics you should monitor and why.

trans-unit.source: Monitoring service health
trans-unit.target: Monitoring service health

trans-unit.source: You can use the Microsoft Azure Portal at https://portal.azure.com to view the health of the Storage service (and other Azure services) in all the Azure regions around the world.
trans-unit.target: You can use the Microsoft Azure Portal at https://portal.azure.com to view the health of the Storage service (and other Azure services) in all the Azure regions around the world.

trans-unit.source: This enables you to see immediately if an issue outside of your control is affecting the Storage service in the region you use for your application.
trans-unit.target: This enables you to see immediately if an issue outside of your control is affecting the Storage service in the region you use for your application.

trans-unit.source: The Azure Portal can also provide with notifications of incidents that affect the various Azure services.
trans-unit.target: The Azure Portal can also provide with notifications of incidents that affect the various Azure services.

trans-unit.source: Note: This information was previously available, along with historical data, on the Azure Service Dashboard at http://status.azure.com.
trans-unit.target: Note: This information was previously available, along with historical data, on the Azure Service Dashboard at http://status.azure.com.

trans-unit.source: While the portal collects health information from inside the Azure datacenters (inside-out monitoring), you could also consider adopting an outside-in approach to generate synthetic transactions that periodically access your Azure-hosted web application from multiple locations.
trans-unit.target: While the portal collects health information from inside the Azure datacenters (inside-out monitoring), you could also consider adopting an outside-in approach to generate synthetic transactions that periodically access your Azure-hosted web application from multiple locations.

trans-unit.source: The services offered by Keynote, Gomez, and Application Insights for Visual Studio Online are examples of this outside-in approach.
trans-unit.target: The services offered by Keynote, Gomez, and Application Insights for Visual Studio Online are examples of this outside-in approach.

trans-unit.source: For more information about Application Insights for Visual Studio Online, see the appendix "[Appendix 5: Monitoring with Application Insights for Visual Studio Online]."
trans-unit.target: For more information about Application Insights for Visual Studio Online, see the appendix "[Appendix 5: Monitoring with Application Insights for Visual Studio Online]."

trans-unit.source: Monitoring capacity
trans-unit.target: Monitoring capacity

trans-unit.source: Storage Metrics only stores capacity metrics for the blob service because blobs typically account for the largest proportion of stored data (at the time of writing, it is not possible to use Storage Metrics to monitor the capacity of your tables and queues).
trans-unit.target: Storage Metrics only stores capacity metrics for the blob service because blobs typically account for the largest proportion of stored data (at the time of writing, it is not possible to use Storage Metrics to monitor the capacity of your tables and queues).

trans-unit.source: You can find this data in the **$MetricsCapacityBlob** table if you have enabled monitoring for the Blob service.
trans-unit.target: You can find this data in the **$MetricsCapacityBlob** table if you have enabled monitoring for the Blob service.

trans-unit.source: Storage Metrics records this data once per day, and you can use the value of the **RowKey** to determine whether the row contains an entity that relates to user data (value **data**) or analytics data (value **analytics**).
trans-unit.target: Storage Metrics records this data once per day, and you can use the value of the **RowKey** to determine whether the row contains an entity that relates to user data (value **data**) or analytics data (value **analytics**).

trans-unit.source: Each stored entity contains information about the amount of storage used (**Capacity** measured in bytes) and the current number of containers (**ContainerCount**) and blobs (**ObjectCount**) in use in the storage account.
trans-unit.target: Each stored entity contains information about the amount of storage used (**Capacity** measured in bytes) and the current number of containers (**ContainerCount**) and blobs (**ObjectCount**) in use in the storage account.

trans-unit.source: For more information about the capacity metrics stored in the **$MetricsCapacityBlob** table, see Storage Analytics Metrics Table Schema on MSDN.
trans-unit.target: For more information about the capacity metrics stored in the **$MetricsCapacityBlob** table, see Storage Analytics Metrics Table Schema on MSDN.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] You should monitor these values for an early warning that you are approaching the capacity limits of your storage account.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] You should monitor these values for an early warning that you are approaching the capacity limits of your storage account.

trans-unit.source: In the Azure portal, on the **Monitor** page for your storage account, you can add alert rules to notify you if aggregate storage use exceeds or falls below thresholds that you specify.
trans-unit.target: In the Azure portal, on the **Monitor** page for your storage account, you can add alert rules to notify you if aggregate storage use exceeds or falls below thresholds that you specify.

trans-unit.source: For help estimating the size of various storage objects such as blobs, see the blog post Understanding Azure Storage Billing – Bandwidth, Transactions, and Capacity.
trans-unit.target: For help estimating the size of various storage objects such as blobs, see the blog post Understanding Azure Storage Billing – Bandwidth, Transactions, and Capacity.

trans-unit.source: Monitoring availability
trans-unit.target: Monitoring availability

trans-unit.source: You should monitor the availability of the storage services in your storage account by monitoring the value in the **Availability** column in the hourly or minute metrics tables — **$MetricsHourPrimaryTransactionsBlob**, **$MetricsHourPrimaryTransactionsTable**, **$MetricsHourPrimaryTransactionsQueue**, **$MetricsMinutePrimaryTransactionsBlob**, **$MetricsMinutePrimaryTransactionsTable**, **$MetricsMinutePrimaryTransactionsQueue**, **$MetricsCapacityBlob**.
trans-unit.target: You should monitor the availability of the storage services in your storage account by monitoring the value in the **Availability** column in the hourly or minute metrics tables — **$MetricsHourPrimaryTransactionsBlob**, **$MetricsHourPrimaryTransactionsTable**, **$MetricsHourPrimaryTransactionsQueue**, **$MetricsMinutePrimaryTransactionsBlob**, **$MetricsMinutePrimaryTransactionsTable**, **$MetricsMinutePrimaryTransactionsQueue**, **$MetricsCapacityBlob**.

trans-unit.source: The **Availability** column contains a percentage value that indicates the availability of the service or the API operation represented by the row (the **RowKey** shows if the row contains metrics for the service as a whole or for a specific API operation).
trans-unit.target: The **Availability** column contains a percentage value that indicates the availability of the service or the API operation represented by the row (the **RowKey** shows if the row contains metrics for the service as a whole or for a specific API operation).

trans-unit.source: Any value less than 100% indicates that some storage requests are failing.
trans-unit.target: Any value less than 100% indicates that some storage requests are failing.

trans-unit.source: You can see why they are failing by examining the other columns in the metrics data that show the numbers of requests with different error types such as **ServerTimeoutError**.
trans-unit.target: You can see why they are failing by examining the other columns in the metrics data that show the numbers of requests with different error types such as **ServerTimeoutError**.

trans-unit.source: You should expect to see **Availability** fall temporarily below 100% for reasons such as transient server timeouts while the service moves partitions to better load-balance request; the retry logic in your client application should handle such intermittent conditions.
trans-unit.target: You should expect to see **Availability** fall temporarily below 100% for reasons such as transient server timeouts while the service moves partitions to better load-balance request; the retry logic in your client application should handle such intermittent conditions.

trans-unit.source: The page lists the transaction types that Storage Metrics includes in its **Availability** calculation.
trans-unit.target: The page lists the transaction types that Storage Metrics includes in its **Availability** calculation.

trans-unit.source: In the Azure portal, on the **Monitor** page for your storage account, you can add alert rules to notify you if **Availability** for a service falls below a threshold that you specify.
trans-unit.target: In the Azure portal, on the **Monitor** page for your storage account, you can add alert rules to notify you if **Availability** for a service falls below a threshold that you specify.

trans-unit.source: The "[Troubleshooting guidance]" section of this guide describes some common storage service issues related to availability.
trans-unit.target: The "[Troubleshooting guidance]" section of this guide describes some common storage service issues related to availability.

trans-unit.source: Monitoring performance
trans-unit.target: Monitoring performance

trans-unit.source: To monitor the performance of the storage services, you can use the following metrics from the hourly and minute metrics tables.
trans-unit.target: To monitor the performance of the storage services, you can use the following metrics from the hourly and minute metrics tables.

trans-unit.source: The values in the **AverageE2ELatency** and **AverageServerLatency** show the average time the storage service or API operation type is taking to process requests.
trans-unit.target: The values in the **AverageE2ELatency** and **AverageServerLatency** show the average time the storage service or API operation type is taking to process requests.

trans-unit.source: **AverageE2ELatency** is a measure of end-to-end latency that includes the time taken to read the request and send the response in addition to the time taken to process the request (therefore includes network latency once the request reaches the storage service); **AverageServerLatency** is a measure of just the processing time and therefore excludes any network latency related to communicating with the client.
trans-unit.target: **AverageE2ELatency** is a measure of end-to-end latency that includes the time taken to read the request and send the response in addition to the time taken to process the request (therefore includes network latency once the request reaches the storage service); **AverageServerLatency** is a measure of just the processing time and therefore excludes any network latency related to communicating with the client.

trans-unit.source: See the section "[Metrics show high AverageE2ELatency and low AverageServerLatency]" later in this guide for a discussion of why there might be a significant difference between these two values.
trans-unit.target: See the section "[Metrics show high AverageE2ELatency and low AverageServerLatency]" later in this guide for a discussion of why there might be a significant difference between these two values.

trans-unit.source: The values in the **TotalIngress** and **TotalEgress** columns show the total amount of data, in bytes, coming in to and going out of your storage service or through a specific API operation type.
trans-unit.target: The values in the **TotalIngress** and **TotalEgress** columns show the total amount of data, in bytes, coming in to and going out of your storage service or through a specific API operation type.

trans-unit.source: The values in the **TotalRequests** column show the total number of requests that the storage service of API operation is receiving.
trans-unit.target: The values in the **TotalRequests** column show the total number of requests that the storage service of API operation is receiving.

trans-unit.source: **TotalRequests** is the total number of requests that the storage service receives.
trans-unit.target: **TotalRequests** is the total number of requests that the storage service receives.

trans-unit.source: Typically, you will monitor for unexpected changes in any of these values as an indicator that you have an issue that requires investigation.
trans-unit.target: Typically, you will monitor for unexpected changes in any of these values as an indicator that you have an issue that requires investigation.

trans-unit.source: In the Azure portal, on the **Monitor** page for your storage account, you can add alert rules to notify you if any of the performance metrics for this service fall below or exceed a threshold that you specify.
trans-unit.target: In the Azure portal, on the **Monitor** page for your storage account, you can add alert rules to notify you if any of the performance metrics for this service fall below or exceed a threshold that you specify.

trans-unit.source: The "[Troubleshooting guidance]" section of this guide describes some common storage service issues related to performance.
trans-unit.target: The "[Troubleshooting guidance]" section of this guide describes some common storage service issues related to performance.

trans-unit.source: Diagnosing storage issues
trans-unit.target: Diagnosing storage issues

trans-unit.source: There are a number of ways that you might become aware of a problem or issue in your application, these include:
trans-unit.target: There are a number of ways that you might become aware of a problem or issue in your application, these include:

trans-unit.source: A major failure that causes the application to crash or to stop working.
trans-unit.target: A major failure that causes the application to crash or to stop working.

trans-unit.source: Significant changes from baseline values in the metrics you are monitoring as described in the previous section "[Monitoring your storage service]."
trans-unit.target: Significant changes from baseline values in the metrics you are monitoring as described in the previous section "[Monitoring your storage service]."

trans-unit.source: Reports from users of your application that some particular operation didn't complete as expected or that some feature is not working.
trans-unit.target: Reports from users of your application that some particular operation didn't complete as expected or that some feature is not working.

trans-unit.source: Errors generated within your application that appear in log files or through some other notification method.
trans-unit.target: Errors generated within your application that appear in log files or through some other notification method.

trans-unit.source: Typically, issues related to Azure storage services fall into one of four broad categories:
trans-unit.target: Typically, issues related to Azure storage services fall into one of four broad categories:

trans-unit.source: Your application has a performance issue, either reported by your users, or revealed by changes in the performance metrics.
trans-unit.target: Your application has a performance issue, either reported by your users, or revealed by changes in the performance metrics.

trans-unit.source: There is a problem with the Azure Storage infrastructure in one or more regions.
trans-unit.target: There is a problem with the Azure Storage infrastructure in one or more regions.

trans-unit.source: Your application is encountering an error, either reported by your users, or revealed by an increase in one of the error count metrics you monitor.
trans-unit.target: Your application is encountering an error, either reported by your users, or revealed by an increase in one of the error count metrics you monitor.

trans-unit.source: During development and test, you may be using the local storage emulator; you may encounter some issues that relate specifically to usage of the storage emulator.
trans-unit.target: During development and test, you may be using the local storage emulator; you may encounter some issues that relate specifically to usage of the storage emulator.

trans-unit.source: The following sections outline the steps you should follow to diagnose and troubleshoot issues in each of these four categories.
trans-unit.target: The following sections outline the steps you should follow to diagnose and troubleshoot issues in each of these four categories.

trans-unit.source: The section "[Troubleshooting guidance]" later in this guide provides more detail for some common issues you may encounter.
trans-unit.target: The section "[Troubleshooting guidance]" later in this guide provides more detail for some common issues you may encounter.

trans-unit.source: Service health issues
trans-unit.target: Service health issues

trans-unit.source: Service health issues are typically outside of your control.
trans-unit.target: Service health issues are typically outside of your control.

trans-unit.source: The Azure Portal provides information about any ongoing issues with Azure services including storage services.
trans-unit.target: The Azure Portal provides information about any ongoing issues with Azure services including storage services.

trans-unit.source: If you opted for Read-Access Geo-Redundant Storage when you created your storage account, then in the event of your data being unavailable in the primary location, your application could switch temporarily to the read-only copy in the secondary location.
trans-unit.target: If you opted for Read-Access Geo-Redundant Storage when you created your storage account, then in the event of your data being unavailable in the primary location, your application could switch temporarily to the read-only copy in the secondary location.

trans-unit.source: To do this, your application must be able to switch between using the primary and secondary storage locations, and be able to work in a reduced functionality mode with read-only data.
trans-unit.target: To do this, your application must be able to switch between using the primary and secondary storage locations, and be able to work in a reduced functionality mode with read-only data.

trans-unit.source: The Azure Storage Client libraries allow you to define a retry policy that can read from secondary storage in case a read from primary storage fails.
trans-unit.target: The Azure Storage Client libraries allow you to define a retry policy that can read from secondary storage in case a read from primary storage fails.

trans-unit.source: Your application also needs to be aware that the data in the secondary location is eventually consistent.
trans-unit.target: Your application also needs to be aware that the data in the secondary location is eventually consistent.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see the blog post Azure Storage Redundancy Options and Read Access Geo Redundant Storage.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see the blog post Azure Storage Redundancy Options and Read Access Geo Redundant Storage.

trans-unit.source: Performance issues
trans-unit.target: Performance issues

trans-unit.source: The performance of an application can be subjective, especially from a user perspective.
trans-unit.target: The performance of an application can be subjective, especially from a user perspective.

trans-unit.source: Therefore, it is important to have baseline metrics available to help you identify where there might be a performance issue.
trans-unit.target: Therefore, it is important to have baseline metrics available to help you identify where there might be a performance issue.

trans-unit.source: Many factors might affect the performance of an Azure storage service from the client application perspective.
trans-unit.target: Many factors might affect the performance of an Azure storage service from the client application perspective.

trans-unit.source: These factors might operate in the storage service, in the client, or in the network infrastructure; therefore it is important to have a strategy for identifying the origin of the performance issue.
trans-unit.target: These factors might operate in the storage service, in the client, or in the network infrastructure; therefore it is important to have a strategy for identifying the origin of the performance issue.

trans-unit.source: After you have identified the likely location of the cause of the performance issue from the metrics, you can then use the log files to find detailed information to diagnose and troubleshoot the problem further.
trans-unit.target: After you have identified the likely location of the cause of the performance issue from the metrics, you can then use the log files to find detailed information to diagnose and troubleshoot the problem further.

trans-unit.source: The section "[Troubleshooting guidance]" later in this guide provides more information about some common performance related issues you may encounter.
trans-unit.target: The section "[Troubleshooting guidance]" later in this guide provides more information about some common performance related issues you may encounter.

trans-unit.source: Diagnosing errors
trans-unit.target: Diagnosing errors

trans-unit.source: Users of your application may notify you of errors reported by the client application.
trans-unit.target: Users of your application may notify you of errors reported by the client application.

trans-unit.source: Storage Metrics also records counts of different error types from your storage services such as **NetworkError**, **ClientTimeoutError**, or **AuthorizationError**.
trans-unit.target: Storage Metrics also records counts of different error types from your storage services such as **NetworkError**, **ClientTimeoutError**, or **AuthorizationError**.

trans-unit.source: While Storage Metrics only records counts of different error types, you can obtain more detail about individual requests by examining server-side, client-side, and network logs.
trans-unit.target: While Storage Metrics only records counts of different error types, you can obtain more detail about individual requests by examining server-side, client-side, and network logs.

trans-unit.source: Typically, the HTTP status code returned by the storage service will give an indication of why the request failed.
trans-unit.target: Typically, the HTTP status code returned by the storage service will give an indication of why the request failed.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] Remember that you should expect to see some intermittent errors: for example, errors due to transient network conditions, or application errors.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] Remember that you should expect to see some intermittent errors: for example, errors due to transient network conditions, or application errors.

trans-unit.source: The following resources on MSDN are useful for understanding storage-related status and error codes:
trans-unit.target: The following resources on MSDN are useful for understanding storage-related status and error codes:

trans-unit.source: Common REST API Error Codes
trans-unit.target: Common REST API Error Codes

trans-unit.source: Blob Service Error Codes
trans-unit.target: Blob Service Error Codes

trans-unit.source: Queue Service Error Codes
trans-unit.target: Queue Service Error Codes

trans-unit.source: Table Service Error Codes
trans-unit.target: Table Service Error Codes

trans-unit.source: Storage emulator issues
trans-unit.target: Storage emulator issues

trans-unit.source: The Azure SDK includes a storage emulator you can run on a development workstation.
trans-unit.target: The Azure SDK includes a storage emulator you can run on a development workstation.

trans-unit.source: This emulator simulates most of the behavior of the Azure storage services and is useful during development and test, enabling you to run applications that use Azure storage services without the need for an Azure subscription and an Azure storage account.
trans-unit.target: This emulator simulates most of the behavior of the Azure storage services and is useful during development and test, enabling you to run applications that use Azure storage services without the need for an Azure subscription and an Azure storage account.

trans-unit.source: The "[Troubleshooting guidance]" section of this guide describes some common issues encountered using the storage emulator.
trans-unit.target: The "[Troubleshooting guidance]" section of this guide describes some common issues encountered using the storage emulator.

trans-unit.source: Storage logging tools
trans-unit.target: Storage logging tools

trans-unit.source: Storage Logging provides server-side logging of storage requests in your Azure storage account.
trans-unit.target: Storage Logging provides server-side logging of storage requests in your Azure storage account.

trans-unit.source: For more information about how to enable server-side logging and access the log data, see Using server-side logging on MSDN.
trans-unit.target: For more information about how to enable server-side logging and access the log data, see Using server-side logging on MSDN.

trans-unit.source: The Storage Client Library for .NET enables you to collect client-side log data that relates to storage operations performed by your application.
trans-unit.target: The Storage Client Library for .NET enables you to collect client-side log data that relates to storage operations performed by your application.

trans-unit.source: For more information about how to enable client-side logging and access the log data, see Client-side logging using the Storage Client Library on MSDN.
trans-unit.target: For more information about how to enable client-side logging and access the log data, see Client-side logging using the Storage Client Library on MSDN.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] In some circumstances (such as SAS authorization failures), a user may report an error for which you can find no request data in the server-side Storage logs.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] In some circumstances (such as SAS authorization failures), a user may report an error for which you can find no request data in the server-side Storage logs.

trans-unit.source: You can use the logging capabilities of the Storage Client Library to investigate if the cause of the issue is on the client or use network monitoring tools to investigate the network.
trans-unit.target: You can use the logging capabilities of the Storage Client Library to investigate if the cause of the issue is on the client or use network monitoring tools to investigate the network.

trans-unit.source: Using network logging tools
trans-unit.target: Using network logging tools

trans-unit.source: You can capture the traffic between the client and server to provide detailed information about the data the client and server are exchanging and the underlying network conditions.
trans-unit.target: You can capture the traffic between the client and server to provide detailed information about the data the client and server are exchanging and the underlying network conditions.

trans-unit.source: Useful network logging tools include:
trans-unit.target: Useful network logging tools include:

trans-unit.source: Fiddler (http://www.telerik.com/fiddler) is a free web debugging proxy that enables you to examine the headers and payload data of HTTP and HTTPS request and response messages.
trans-unit.target: Fiddler (http://www.telerik.com/fiddler) is a free web debugging proxy that enables you to examine the headers and payload data of HTTP and HTTPS request and response messages.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see "[Appendix 1: Using Fiddler to capture HTTP and HTTPS traffic]".
trans-unit.target: For more information, see "[Appendix 1: Using Fiddler to capture HTTP and HTTPS traffic]".

trans-unit.source: Microsoft Network Monitor (Netmon) (http://www.microsoft.com/download/details.aspx?id=4865) and Wireshark (http://www.wireshark.org/) are free network protocol analyzers that enable you to view detailed packet information for a wide range of network protocols.
trans-unit.target: Microsoft Network Monitor (Netmon) (http://www.microsoft.com/download/details.aspx?id=4865) and Wireshark (http://www.wireshark.org/) are free network protocol analyzers that enable you to view detailed packet information for a wide range of network protocols.

trans-unit.source: For more information about Wireshark, see "[Appendix 2: Using Wireshark to capture network traffic]".
trans-unit.target: For more information about Wireshark, see "[Appendix 2: Using Wireshark to capture network traffic]".

trans-unit.source: Microsoft Message Analyzer is a tool from Microsoft that supersedes Netmon and that in addition to capturing network packet data, helps you to view and analyze the log data captured from other tools.
trans-unit.target: Microsoft Message Analyzer is a tool from Microsoft that supersedes Netmon and that in addition to capturing network packet data, helps you to view and analyze the log data captured from other tools.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see "[Appendix 3: Using Microsoft Message Analyzer to capture network traffic]".
trans-unit.target: For more information, see "[Appendix 3: Using Microsoft Message Analyzer to capture network traffic]".

trans-unit.source: If you want to perform a basic connectivity test to check that your client machine can connect to the Azure storage service over the network, you cannot do this using the standard **ping** tool on the client.
trans-unit.target: If you want to perform a basic connectivity test to check that your client machine can connect to the Azure storage service over the network, you cannot do this using the standard **ping** tool on the client.

trans-unit.source: However, you can use the **tcping** tool to check connectivity.
trans-unit.target: However, you can use the **tcping** tool to check connectivity.

trans-unit.source: **Tcping** is available for download at http://www.elifulkerson.com/projects/tcping.php.
trans-unit.target: **Tcping** is available for download at http://www.elifulkerson.com/projects/tcping.php.

trans-unit.source: In many cases, the log data from Storage Logging and the Storage Client Library will be sufficient to diagnose an issue, but in some scenarios, you may need the more detailed information that these network logging tools can provide.
trans-unit.target: In many cases, the log data from Storage Logging and the Storage Client Library will be sufficient to diagnose an issue, but in some scenarios, you may need the more detailed information that these network logging tools can provide.

trans-unit.source: For example, using Fiddler to view HTTP and HTTPS messages enables you to view header and payload data sent to and from the storage services, which would enable you to examine how a client application retries storage operations.
trans-unit.target: For example, using Fiddler to view HTTP and HTTPS messages enables you to view header and payload data sent to and from the storage services, which would enable you to examine how a client application retries storage operations.

trans-unit.source: Protocol analyzers such as Wireshark operate at the packet level enabling you to view TCP data, which would enable you to troubleshoot lost packets and connectivity issues.
trans-unit.target: Protocol analyzers such as Wireshark operate at the packet level enabling you to view TCP data, which would enable you to troubleshoot lost packets and connectivity issues.

trans-unit.source: Message Analyzer can operate at both HTTP and TCP layers.
trans-unit.target: Message Analyzer can operate at both HTTP and TCP layers.

trans-unit.source: End-to-end tracing
trans-unit.target: End-to-end tracing

trans-unit.source: End-to-end tracing using a variety of log files is a useful technique for investigating potential issues.
trans-unit.target: End-to-end tracing using a variety of log files is a useful technique for investigating potential issues.

trans-unit.source: You can use the date/time information from your metrics data as an indication of where to start looking in the log files for the detailed information that will help you troubleshoot the issue.
trans-unit.target: You can use the date/time information from your metrics data as an indication of where to start looking in the log files for the detailed information that will help you troubleshoot the issue.

trans-unit.source: Correlating log data
trans-unit.target: Correlating log data

trans-unit.source: When viewing logs from client applications, network traces, and server-side storage logging it is critical to be able to correlate requests across the different log files.
trans-unit.target: When viewing logs from client applications, network traces, and server-side storage logging it is critical to be able to correlate requests across the different log files.

trans-unit.source: The log files include a number of different fields that are useful as correlation identifiers.
trans-unit.target: The log files include a number of different fields that are useful as correlation identifiers.

trans-unit.source: The client request id is the most useful field to use to correlate entries in the different logs.
trans-unit.target: The client request id is the most useful field to use to correlate entries in the different logs.

trans-unit.source: However sometimes, it can be useful to use either the server request id or timestamps.
trans-unit.target: However sometimes, it can be useful to use either the server request id or timestamps.

trans-unit.source: The following sections provide more details about these options.
trans-unit.target: The following sections provide more details about these options.

trans-unit.source: Client request ID
trans-unit.target: Client request ID

trans-unit.source: The Storage Client Library automatically generates a unique client request id for every request.
trans-unit.target: The Storage Client Library automatically generates a unique client request id for every request.

trans-unit.source: In the client-side log that the Storage Client Library creates, the client request id appears in the **Client Request ID** field of every log entry relating to the request.
trans-unit.target: In the client-side log that the Storage Client Library creates, the client request id appears in the **Client Request ID** field of every log entry relating to the request.

trans-unit.source: In a network trace such as one captured by Fiddler, the client request id is visible in request messages as the **x-ms-client-request-id** HTTP header value.
trans-unit.target: In a network trace such as one captured by Fiddler, the client request id is visible in request messages as the **x-ms-client-request-id** HTTP header value.

trans-unit.source: In the server-side Storage Logging log, the client request id appears in the Client request ID column.
trans-unit.target: In the server-side Storage Logging log, the client request id appears in the Client request ID column.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] It is possible for multiple requests to share the same client request id because the client can assign this value (although the Storage Client Library assigns a
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] It is possible for multiple requests to share the same client request id because the client can assign this value (although the Storage Client Library assigns a

trans-unit.source: new value automatically).
trans-unit.target: new value automatically).

trans-unit.source: In the case of retries from the client, all attempts share the same client request id.
trans-unit.target: In the case of retries from the client, all attempts share the same client request id.

trans-unit.source: In the case of a batch sent from the client, the batch has a single client request id.
trans-unit.target: In the case of a batch sent from the client, the batch has a single client request id.

trans-unit.source: Server request ID
trans-unit.target: Server request ID

trans-unit.source: The storage service automatically generates server request ids.
trans-unit.target: The storage service automatically generates server request ids.

trans-unit.source: In the server-side Storage Logging log, the server request id appears the **Request ID header** column.
trans-unit.target: In the server-side Storage Logging log, the server request id appears the **Request ID header** column.

trans-unit.source: In a network trace such as one captured by Fiddler, the server request id appears in response messages as the **x-ms-request-id** HTTP header value.
trans-unit.target: In a network trace such as one captured by Fiddler, the server request id appears in response messages as the **x-ms-request-id** HTTP header value.

trans-unit.source: In the client-side log that the Storage Client Library creates, the server request id appears in the **Operation Text** column for the log entry showing details of the server response.
trans-unit.target: In the client-side log that the Storage Client Library creates, the server request id appears in the **Operation Text** column for the log entry showing details of the server response.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] The storage service always assigns a unique server request id to every request it receives, so every retry attempt from the client and every operation included in a batch has a unique server request id.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] The storage service always assigns a unique server request id to every request it receives, so every retry attempt from the client and every operation included in a batch has a unique server request id.

trans-unit.source: If the Storage Client Library throws a **StorageException** in the client, the **RequestInformation** property contains a **RequestResult** object that includes a **ServiceRequestID** property.
trans-unit.target: If the Storage Client Library throws a **StorageException** in the client, the **RequestInformation** property contains a **RequestResult** object that includes a **ServiceRequestID** property.

trans-unit.source: You can also access a **RequestResult** object from an **OperationContext** instance.
trans-unit.target: You can also access a **RequestResult** object from an **OperationContext** instance.

trans-unit.source: The code sample below demonstrates how to set a custom **ClientRequestId** value by attaching an **OperationContext** object the request to the storage service.
trans-unit.target: The code sample below demonstrates how to set a custom **ClientRequestId** value by attaching an **OperationContext** object the request to the storage service.

trans-unit.source: It also shows how to retrieve the **ServerRequestId** value from the response message.
trans-unit.target: It also shows how to retrieve the **ServerRequestId** value from the response message.

trans-unit.source: Timestamps
trans-unit.target: Timestamps

trans-unit.source: You can also use timestamps to locate related log entries, but be careful of any clock skew between the client and server that may exist.
trans-unit.target: You can also use timestamps to locate related log entries, but be careful of any clock skew between the client and server that may exist.

trans-unit.source: You should search plus or minus 15 minutes for matching server-side entries based on the timestamp on the client.
trans-unit.target: You should search plus or minus 15 minutes for matching server-side entries based on the timestamp on the client.

trans-unit.source: Remember that the blob metadata for the blobs containing metrics indicates the time range for the metrics stored in the blob; this is useful if you have many metrics blobs for the same minute or hour.
trans-unit.target: Remember that the blob metadata for the blobs containing metrics indicates the time range for the metrics stored in the blob; this is useful if you have many metrics blobs for the same minute or hour.

trans-unit.source: Troubleshooting guidance
trans-unit.target: Troubleshooting guidance

trans-unit.source: This section will help you with the diagnosis and troubleshooting of some of the common issues your application may encounter when using the Azure storage services.
trans-unit.target: This section will help you with the diagnosis and troubleshooting of some of the common issues your application may encounter when using the Azure storage services.

trans-unit.source: Use the list below to locate the information relevant to your specific issue.
trans-unit.target: Use the list below to locate the information relevant to your specific issue.

trans-unit.source: Troubleshooting Decision Tree
trans-unit.target: Troubleshooting Decision Tree

trans-unit.source: Does your issue relate to the performance of one of the storage services?
trans-unit.target: Does your issue relate to the performance of one of the storage services?

trans-unit.source: [Metrics show high AverageE2ELatency and low AverageServerLatency]
trans-unit.target: [Metrics show high AverageE2ELatency and low AverageServerLatency]

trans-unit.source: [Metrics show low AverageE2ELatency and low AverageServerLatency but the client is experiencing high latency]
trans-unit.target: [Metrics show low AverageE2ELatency and low AverageServerLatency but the client is experiencing high latency]

trans-unit.source: [Metrics show high AverageServerLatency]
trans-unit.target: [Metrics show high AverageServerLatency]

trans-unit.source: [You are experiencing unexpected delays in message delivery on a queue]
trans-unit.target: [You are experiencing unexpected delays in message delivery on a queue]

trans-unit.source: Does your issue relate to the availability of one of the storage services?
trans-unit.target: Does your issue relate to the availability of one of the storage services?

trans-unit.source: [Metrics show an increase in PercentThrottlingError]
trans-unit.target: [Metrics show an increase in PercentThrottlingError]

trans-unit.source: [Metrics show an increase in PercentTimeoutError]
trans-unit.target: [Metrics show an increase in PercentTimeoutError]

trans-unit.source: [Metrics show an increase in PercentNetworkError]
trans-unit.target: [Metrics show an increase in PercentNetworkError]

trans-unit.source: Is your client application receiving an HTTP 4XX (such as 404) response from a storage service?
trans-unit.target: Is your client application receiving an HTTP 4XX (such as 404) response from a storage service?

trans-unit.source: [The client is receiving HTTP 403 (Forbidden) messages]
trans-unit.target: [The client is receiving HTTP 403 (Forbidden) messages]

trans-unit.source: [The client is receiving HTTP 404 (Not found) messages]
trans-unit.target: [The client is receiving HTTP 404 (Not found) messages]

trans-unit.source: [The client is receiving HTTP 409 (Conflict) messages]
trans-unit.target: [The client is receiving HTTP 409 (Conflict) messages]

trans-unit.source: [Metrics show low PercentSuccess or analytics log entries have operations with transaction status of ClientOtherErrors]
trans-unit.target: [Metrics show low PercentSuccess or analytics log entries have operations with transaction status of ClientOtherErrors]

trans-unit.source: [Capacity metrics show an unexpected increase in storage capacity usage]
trans-unit.target: [Capacity metrics show an unexpected increase in storage capacity usage]

trans-unit.source: [You are experiencing unexpected reboots of Virtual Machines that have a large number of attached VHDs]
trans-unit.target: [You are experiencing unexpected reboots of Virtual Machines that have a large number of attached VHDs]

trans-unit.source: [Your issue arises from using the storage emulator for development or test]
trans-unit.target: [Your issue arises from using the storage emulator for development or test]

trans-unit.source: [You are encountering problems installing the Azure SDK for .NET]
trans-unit.target: [You are encountering problems installing the Azure SDK for .NET]

trans-unit.source: [You have a different issue with a storage service]
trans-unit.target: [You have a different issue with a storage service]

trans-unit.source: Metrics show high AverageE2ELatency and low AverageServerLatency
trans-unit.target: Metrics show high AverageE2ELatency and low AverageServerLatency

trans-unit.source: The illustration blow from the portal monitoring tool shows an example where the **AverageE2ELatency** is significantly higher than the **AverageServerLatency**.
trans-unit.target: The illustration blow from the portal monitoring tool shows an example where the **AverageE2ELatency** is significantly higher than the **AverageServerLatency**.

trans-unit.source: Note that the storage service only calculates the metric **AverageE2ELatency** for successful requests and, unlike **AverageServerLatency**, includes the time the client takes to send the data and receive acknowledgement from the storage service.
trans-unit.target: Note that the storage service only calculates the metric **AverageE2ELatency** for successful requests and, unlike **AverageServerLatency**, includes the time the client takes to send the data and receive acknowledgement from the storage service.

trans-unit.source: Therefore, a difference between **AverageE2ELatency** and **AverageServerLatency** could be either due to the client application being slow to respond, or due to conditions on the network.
trans-unit.target: Therefore, a difference between **AverageE2ELatency** and **AverageServerLatency** could be either due to the client application being slow to respond, or due to conditions on the network.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] You can also view **E2ELatency** and **ServerLatency** for individual storage operations in the Storage Logging log data.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] You can also view **E2ELatency** and **ServerLatency** for individual storage operations in the Storage Logging log data.

trans-unit.source: Investigating client performance issues
trans-unit.target: Investigating client performance issues

trans-unit.source: Possible reasons for the client responding slowly include having a limited number of available connections or threads.
trans-unit.target: Possible reasons for the client responding slowly include having a limited number of available connections or threads.

trans-unit.source: You may be able to resolve the issue by modifying the client code to be more efficient (for example by using asynchronous calls to the storage service), or by using a larger Virtual Machine (with more cores and more memory).
trans-unit.target: You may be able to resolve the issue by modifying the client code to be more efficient (for example by using asynchronous calls to the storage service), or by using a larger Virtual Machine (with more cores and more memory).

trans-unit.source: For the table and queue services, the Nagle algorithm can also cause high **AverageE2ELatency** as compared to **AverageServerLatency**: for more information see the post Nagle’s Algorithm is Not Friendly towards Small Requests on the Microsoft Azure Storage Team Blog.
trans-unit.target: For the table and queue services, the Nagle algorithm can also cause high **AverageE2ELatency** as compared to **AverageServerLatency**: for more information see the post Nagle’s Algorithm is Not Friendly towards Small Requests on the Microsoft Azure Storage Team Blog.

trans-unit.source: You can disable the Nagle algorithm in code by using the **ServicePointManager** class in the **System.Net** namespace.
trans-unit.target: You can disable the Nagle algorithm in code by using the **ServicePointManager** class in the **System.Net** namespace.

trans-unit.source: You should do this before you make any calls to the table or queue services in your application since this does not affect connections that are already open.
trans-unit.target: You should do this before you make any calls to the table or queue services in your application since this does not affect connections that are already open.

trans-unit.source: The following example comes from the **Application_Start** method in a worker role.
trans-unit.target: The following example comes from the **Application_Start** method in a worker role.

trans-unit.source: You should check the client-side logs to see how many requests your client application is submitting, and check for general .NET related performance bottlenecks in your client such as CPU, .NET garbage collection, network utilization, or memory (as a starting point for troubleshooting .NET client applications, see Debugging, Tracing, and Profiling on MSDN).
trans-unit.target: You should check the client-side logs to see how many requests your client application is submitting, and check for general .NET related performance bottlenecks in your client such as CPU, .NET garbage collection, network utilization, or memory (as a starting point for troubleshooting .NET client applications, see Debugging, Tracing, and Profiling on MSDN).

trans-unit.source: Investigating network latency issues
trans-unit.target: Investigating network latency issues

trans-unit.source: Typically, high end-to-end latency caused by the network is due to transient conditions.
trans-unit.target: Typically, high end-to-end latency caused by the network is due to transient conditions.

trans-unit.source: You can investigate both transient and persistent network issues such as dropped packets by using tools such as Wireshark or Microsoft Message Analyzer.
trans-unit.target: You can investigate both transient and persistent network issues such as dropped packets by using tools such as Wireshark or Microsoft Message Analyzer.

trans-unit.source: For more information about using Wireshark to troubleshoot network issues, see "[Appendix 2: Using Wireshark to capture network traffic]."
trans-unit.target: For more information about using Wireshark to troubleshoot network issues, see "[Appendix 2: Using Wireshark to capture network traffic]."

trans-unit.source: For more information about using Microsoft Message Analyzer to troubleshoot network issues, see "[Appendix 3: Using Microsoft Message Analyzer to capture network traffic]."
trans-unit.target: For more information about using Microsoft Message Analyzer to troubleshoot network issues, see "[Appendix 3: Using Microsoft Message Analyzer to capture network traffic]."

trans-unit.source: Metrics show low AverageE2ELatency and low AverageServerLatency but the client is experiencing high latency
trans-unit.target: Metrics show low AverageE2ELatency and low AverageServerLatency but the client is experiencing high latency

trans-unit.source: In this scenario, the most likely cause is a delay in the storage requests reaching the storage service.
trans-unit.target: In this scenario, the most likely cause is a delay in the storage requests reaching the storage service.

trans-unit.source: You should investigate why requests from the client are not making it through to the blob service.
trans-unit.target: You should investigate why requests from the client are not making it through to the blob service.

trans-unit.source: Possible reasons for the client delaying sending requests include having a limited number of available connections or threads.
trans-unit.target: Possible reasons for the client delaying sending requests include having a limited number of available connections or threads.

trans-unit.source: You should also check if the client is performing multiple retries, and investigate the reason if this is the case.
trans-unit.target: You should also check if the client is performing multiple retries, and investigate the reason if this is the case.

trans-unit.source: You can do this programmatically by looking in the **OperationContext** object associated with the request and retrieving the **ServerRequestId** value.
trans-unit.target: You can do this programmatically by looking in the **OperationContext** object associated with the request and retrieving the **ServerRequestId** value.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see the code sample in the section "[Server request ID]."
trans-unit.target: For more information, see the code sample in the section "[Server request ID]."

trans-unit.source: If there are no issues in the client, you should investigate potential network issues such as packet loss.
trans-unit.target: If there are no issues in the client, you should investigate potential network issues such as packet loss.

trans-unit.source: You can use tools such as Wireshark or Microsoft Message Analyzer to investigate network issues.
trans-unit.target: You can use tools such as Wireshark or Microsoft Message Analyzer to investigate network issues.

trans-unit.source: For more information about using Wireshark to troubleshoot network issues, see "[Appendix 2: Using Wireshark to capture network traffic]."
trans-unit.target: For more information about using Wireshark to troubleshoot network issues, see "[Appendix 2: Using Wireshark to capture network traffic]."

trans-unit.source: For more information about using Microsoft Message Analyzer to troubleshoot network issues, see "[Appendix 3: Using Microsoft Message Analyzer to capture network traffic]."
trans-unit.target: For more information about using Microsoft Message Analyzer to troubleshoot network issues, see "[Appendix 3: Using Microsoft Message Analyzer to capture network traffic]."

trans-unit.source: Metrics show high AverageServerLatency
trans-unit.target: Metrics show high AverageServerLatency

trans-unit.source: In the case of high **AverageServerLatency** for blob download requests, you should use the Storage Logging logs to see if there are repeated requests for the same blob (or set of blobs).
trans-unit.target: In the case of high **AverageServerLatency** for blob download requests, you should use the Storage Logging logs to see if there are repeated requests for the same blob (or set of blobs).

trans-unit.source: For blob upload requests, you should investigate what block size the client is using (for example, blocks less than 64K in size can result in overheads unless the reads are also in less than 64K chunks), and if multiple clients are uploading blocks to the same blob in parallel.
trans-unit.target: For blob upload requests, you should investigate what block size the client is using (for example, blocks less than 64K in size can result in overheads unless the reads are also in less than 64K chunks), and if multiple clients are uploading blocks to the same blob in parallel.

trans-unit.source: You should also check the per-minute metrics for spikes in the number of requests that result in exceeding the per second scalability targets: also see "[Metrics show an increase in PercentTimeoutError]."
trans-unit.target: You should also check the per-minute metrics for spikes in the number of requests that result in exceeding the per second scalability targets: also see "[Metrics show an increase in PercentTimeoutError]."

trans-unit.source: If you are seeing high **AverageServerLatency** for blob download requests when there are repeated requests the same blob or set of blobs, then you should consider caching these blobs using Azure Cache or the Azure Content Delivery Network (CDN).
trans-unit.target: If you are seeing high **AverageServerLatency** for blob download requests when there are repeated requests the same blob or set of blobs, then you should consider caching these blobs using Azure Cache or the Azure Content Delivery Network (CDN).

trans-unit.source: For upload requests, you can improve the throughput by using a larger block size.
trans-unit.target: For upload requests, you can improve the throughput by using a larger block size.

trans-unit.source: For queries to tables, it is also possible to implement client-side caching on clients that perform the same query operations and where the data doesn’t change frequently.
trans-unit.target: For queries to tables, it is also possible to implement client-side caching on clients that perform the same query operations and where the data doesn’t change frequently.

trans-unit.source: High **AverageServerLatency** values can also be a symptom of poorly designed tables or queries that result in scan operations or that follow the append/prepend anti-pattern.
trans-unit.target: High **AverageServerLatency** values can also be a symptom of poorly designed tables or queries that result in scan operations or that follow the append/prepend anti-pattern.

trans-unit.source: See "[Metrics show an increase in PercentThrottlingError]" for more information.
trans-unit.target: See "[Metrics show an increase in PercentThrottlingError]" for more information.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] You can find a comprehensive checklist including other issues to be aware here: "Designing Scalable and Performant Storage Based Applications Checklist."
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] You can find a comprehensive checklist including other issues to be aware here: "Designing Scalable and Performant Storage Based Applications Checklist."

trans-unit.source: You are experiencing unexpected delays in message delivery on a queue
trans-unit.target: You are experiencing unexpected delays in message delivery on a queue

trans-unit.source: If you are experiencing a delay between the time an application adds a message to a queue and the time it becomes available to read from the queue, then you should take the following steps to diagnose the issue:
trans-unit.target: If you are experiencing a delay between the time an application adds a message to a queue and the time it becomes available to read from the queue, then you should take the following steps to diagnose the issue:

trans-unit.source: Verify the application is successfully adding the messages to the queue.
trans-unit.target: Verify the application is successfully adding the messages to the queue.

trans-unit.source: Check that the application is not retrying the **AddMessage** method several times before succeeding.
trans-unit.target: Check that the application is not retrying the **AddMessage** method several times before succeeding.

trans-unit.source: The Storage Client Library logs will show any repeated retries of storage operations.
trans-unit.target: The Storage Client Library logs will show any repeated retries of storage operations.

trans-unit.source: Verify there is no clock skew between the worker role that adds the message to the queue and the worker role that reads the message from the queue that makes it appear as if there is a delay in processing.
trans-unit.target: Verify there is no clock skew between the worker role that adds the message to the queue and the worker role that reads the message from the queue that makes it appear as if there is a delay in processing.

trans-unit.source: Check if the worker role that reads the messages from the queue is failing.
trans-unit.target: Check if the worker role that reads the messages from the queue is failing.

trans-unit.source: If a queue client calls the **GetMessage** method but fails to respond with an acknowledgement, the message will remain invisible on the queue until the **invisibilityTimeout** period expires.
trans-unit.target: If a queue client calls the **GetMessage** method but fails to respond with an acknowledgement, the message will remain invisible on the queue until the **invisibilityTimeout** period expires.

trans-unit.source: At this point, the message becomes available for processing again.
trans-unit.target: At this point, the message becomes available for processing again.

trans-unit.source: Check if the queue length is growing over time.
trans-unit.target: Check if the queue length is growing over time.

trans-unit.source: This can occur if you do not have sufficient workers available to process all of the messages that other workers are placing on the queue.
trans-unit.target: This can occur if you do not have sufficient workers available to process all of the messages that other workers are placing on the queue.

trans-unit.source: You should also check the metrics to see if delete requests are failing and the dequeue count on messages, which might indicate repeated failed attempts to delete the message.
trans-unit.target: You should also check the metrics to see if delete requests are failing and the dequeue count on messages, which might indicate repeated failed attempts to delete the message.

trans-unit.source: Examine the Storage Logging logs for any queue operations that have higher than expected **E2ELatency** and **ServerLatency** values over a longer period of time than usual.
trans-unit.target: Examine the Storage Logging logs for any queue operations that have higher than expected **E2ELatency** and **ServerLatency** values over a longer period of time than usual.

trans-unit.source: Metrics show an increase in PercentThrottlingError
trans-unit.target: Metrics show an increase in PercentThrottlingError

trans-unit.source: Throttling errors occur when you exceed the scalability targets of a storage service.
trans-unit.target: Throttling errors occur when you exceed the scalability targets of a storage service.

trans-unit.source: The storage service does this to ensure that no single client or tenant can use the service at the expense of others.
trans-unit.target: The storage service does this to ensure that no single client or tenant can use the service at the expense of others.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see Azure Storage Scalability and Performance Targets for details on scalability targets for storage accounts and performance targets for partitions within storage accounts.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see Azure Storage Scalability and Performance Targets for details on scalability targets for storage accounts and performance targets for partitions within storage accounts.

trans-unit.source: If the **PercentThrottlingError** metric show an increase in the percentage of requests that are failing with a throttling error, you need to investigate one of two scenarios:
trans-unit.target: If the **PercentThrottlingError** metric show an increase in the percentage of requests that are failing with a throttling error, you need to investigate one of two scenarios:

trans-unit.source: [Transient increase in PercentThrottlingError]
trans-unit.target: [Transient increase in PercentThrottlingError]

trans-unit.source: [Permanent increase in PercentThrottlingError error]
trans-unit.target: [Permanent increase in PercentThrottlingError error]

trans-unit.source: An increase in **PercentThrottlingError** often occurs at the same time as an increase in the number of storage requests, or when you are initially load testing your application.
trans-unit.target: An increase in **PercentThrottlingError** often occurs at the same time as an increase in the number of storage requests, or when you are initially load testing your application.

trans-unit.source: This may also manifest itself in the client as "503 Server Busy" or "500 Operation Timeout" HTTP status messages from storage operations.
trans-unit.target: This may also manifest itself in the client as "503 Server Busy" or "500 Operation Timeout" HTTP status messages from storage operations.

trans-unit.source: Transient increase in PercentThrottlingError
trans-unit.target: Transient increase in PercentThrottlingError

trans-unit.source: If you are seeing spikes in the value of **PercentThrottlingError** that coincide with periods of high activity for the application, you should implement an exponential (not linear) back off strategy for retries in your client: this will reduce the immediate load on the partition and help your application to smooth out spikes in traffic.
