trans-unit.target: If you are seeing spikes in the value of **PercentThrottlingError** that coincide with periods of high activity for the application, you should implement an exponential (not linear) back off strategy for retries in your client: this will reduce the immediate load on the partition and help your application to smooth out spikes in traffic.

trans-unit.source: For more information about how to implement retry policies using the Storage Client Library, see Microsoft.WindowsAzure.Storage.RetryPolicies Namespace on MSDN.
trans-unit.target: For more information about how to implement retry policies using the Storage Client Library, see Microsoft.WindowsAzure.Storage.RetryPolicies Namespace on MSDN.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] You may also see spikes in the value of **PercentThrottlingError** that do not coincide with periods of high activity for the application: the most likely cause here is the storage service moving partitions to improve load balancing.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] You may also see spikes in the value of **PercentThrottlingError** that do not coincide with periods of high activity for the application: the most likely cause here is the storage service moving partitions to improve load balancing.

trans-unit.source: Permanent increase in PercentThrottlingError error
trans-unit.target: Permanent increase in PercentThrottlingError error

trans-unit.source: If you are seeing a consistently high value for **PercentThrottlingError** following a permanent increase in your transaction volumes, or when you are performing your initial load tests on your application, then you need to evaluate how your application is using storage partitions and whether it is approaching the scalability targets for a storage account.
trans-unit.target: If you are seeing a consistently high value for **PercentThrottlingError** following a permanent increase in your transaction volumes, or when you are performing your initial load tests on your application, then you need to evaluate how your application is using storage partitions and whether it is approaching the scalability targets for a storage account.

trans-unit.source: For example, if you are seeing throttling errors on a queue (which counts as a single partition), then you should consider using additional queues to spread the transactions across multiple partitions.
trans-unit.target: For example, if you are seeing throttling errors on a queue (which counts as a single partition), then you should consider using additional queues to spread the transactions across multiple partitions.

trans-unit.source: If you are seeing throttling errors on a table, you need to consider using a different partitioning scheme to spread your transactions across multiple partitions by using a wider range of partition key values.
trans-unit.target: If you are seeing throttling errors on a table, you need to consider using a different partitioning scheme to spread your transactions across multiple partitions by using a wider range of partition key values.

trans-unit.source: One common cause of this issue is the prepend/append anti-pattern where you select the date as the partition key and then all data on a particular day is written to one partition: under load, this can result in a write bottleneck.
trans-unit.target: One common cause of this issue is the prepend/append anti-pattern where you select the date as the partition key and then all data on a particular day is written to one partition: under load, this can result in a write bottleneck.

trans-unit.source: You should either consider a different partitioning design or evaluate whether using blob storage might be a better solution.
trans-unit.target: You should either consider a different partitioning design or evaluate whether using blob storage might be a better solution.

trans-unit.source: You should also check if the throttling is occurring as a result of spikes in your traffic and investigate ways of smoothing your pattern of requests.
trans-unit.target: You should also check if the throttling is occurring as a result of spikes in your traffic and investigate ways of smoothing your pattern of requests.

trans-unit.source: If you distribute your transactions across multiple partitions, you must still be aware of the scalability limits set for the storage account.
trans-unit.target: If you distribute your transactions across multiple partitions, you must still be aware of the scalability limits set for the storage account.

trans-unit.source: For example, if you used ten queues each processing the maximum of 2,000 1KB messages per second, you will be at the overall limit of 20,000 messages per second for the storage account.
trans-unit.target: For example, if you used ten queues each processing the maximum of 2,000 1KB messages per second, you will be at the overall limit of 20,000 messages per second for the storage account.

trans-unit.source: If you need to process more than 20,000 entities per second, you should consider using multiple storage accounts.
trans-unit.target: If you need to process more than 20,000 entities per second, you should consider using multiple storage accounts.

trans-unit.source: You should also bear in mind that the size of your requests and entities has an impact on when the storage service throttles your clients: if you have larger requests and entities, you may be throttled sooner.
trans-unit.target: You should also bear in mind that the size of your requests and entities has an impact on when the storage service throttles your clients: if you have larger requests and entities, you may be throttled sooner.

trans-unit.source: Inefficient query design can also cause you to hit the scalability limits for table partitions.
trans-unit.target: Inefficient query design can also cause you to hit the scalability limits for table partitions.

trans-unit.source: For example, a query with a filter that only selects one percent of the entities in a partition but that scans all the entities in a partition will need to access each entity.
trans-unit.target: For example, a query with a filter that only selects one percent of the entities in a partition but that scans all the entities in a partition will need to access each entity.

trans-unit.source: Every entity read will count towards the total number of transactions in that partition; therefore, you can easily reach the scalability targets.
trans-unit.target: Every entity read will count towards the total number of transactions in that partition; therefore, you can easily reach the scalability targets.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] Your performance testing should reveal any inefficient query designs in your application.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] Your performance testing should reveal any inefficient query designs in your application.

trans-unit.source: Metrics show an increase in PercentTimeoutError
trans-unit.target: Metrics show an increase in PercentTimeoutError

trans-unit.source: Your metrics show an increase in **PercentTimeoutError** for one of your storage services.
trans-unit.target: Your metrics show an increase in **PercentTimeoutError** for one of your storage services.

trans-unit.source: At the same time, the client receives a high volume of "500 Operation Timeout" HTTP status messages from storage operations.
trans-unit.target: At the same time, the client receives a high volume of "500 Operation Timeout" HTTP status messages from storage operations.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] You may see timeout errors temporarily as the storage service load balances requests by moving a partition to a new server.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] You may see timeout errors temporarily as the storage service load balances requests by moving a partition to a new server.

trans-unit.source: The **PercentTimeoutError** metric is an aggregation of the following metrics: **ClientTimeoutError**, **AnonymousClientTimeoutError**, **SASClientTimeoutError**, **ServerTimeoutError**, **AnonymousServerTimeoutError**, and **SASServerTimeoutError**.
trans-unit.target: The **PercentTimeoutError** metric is an aggregation of the following metrics: **ClientTimeoutError**, **AnonymousClientTimeoutError**, **SASClientTimeoutError**, **ServerTimeoutError**, **AnonymousServerTimeoutError**, and **SASServerTimeoutError**.

trans-unit.source: The server timeouts are caused by an error on the server.
trans-unit.target: The server timeouts are caused by an error on the server.

trans-unit.source: The client timeouts happen because an operation on the server has exceeded the timeout specified by the client; for example, a client using the Storage Client Library can set a timeout for an operation by using the **ServerTimeout** property of the **QueueRequestOptions** class.
trans-unit.target: The client timeouts happen because an operation on the server has exceeded the timeout specified by the client; for example, a client using the Storage Client Library can set a timeout for an operation by using the **ServerTimeout** property of the **QueueRequestOptions** class.

trans-unit.source: Server timeouts indicate a problem with the storage service that requires further investigation.
trans-unit.target: Server timeouts indicate a problem with the storage service that requires further investigation.

trans-unit.source: You can use metrics to see if you are hitting the scalability limits for the service and to identify any spikes in traffic that might be causing this problem.
trans-unit.target: You can use metrics to see if you are hitting the scalability limits for the service and to identify any spikes in traffic that might be causing this problem.

trans-unit.source: If the problem is intermittent, it may be due to load-balancing activity in the service.
trans-unit.target: If the problem is intermittent, it may be due to load-balancing activity in the service.

trans-unit.source: If the problem is persistent and is not caused by your application hitting the scalability limits of the service, you should raise a support issue.
trans-unit.target: If the problem is persistent and is not caused by your application hitting the scalability limits of the service, you should raise a support issue.

trans-unit.source: For client timeouts, you must decide if the timeout is set to an appropriate value in the client and either change the timeout value set in the client or investigate how you can improve the performance of the operations in the storage service, for example by optimizing your table queries or reducing the size of your messages.
trans-unit.target: For client timeouts, you must decide if the timeout is set to an appropriate value in the client and either change the timeout value set in the client or investigate how you can improve the performance of the operations in the storage service, for example by optimizing your table queries or reducing the size of your messages.

trans-unit.source: Metrics show an increase in PercentNetworkError
trans-unit.target: Metrics show an increase in PercentNetworkError

trans-unit.source: Your metrics show an increase in **PercentNetworkError** for one of your storage services.
trans-unit.target: Your metrics show an increase in **PercentNetworkError** for one of your storage services.

trans-unit.source: The **PercentNetworkError** metric is an aggregation of the following metrics: **NetworkError**, **AnonymousNetworkError**, and **SASNetworkError**.
trans-unit.target: The **PercentNetworkError** metric is an aggregation of the following metrics: **NetworkError**, **AnonymousNetworkError**, and **SASNetworkError**.

trans-unit.source: These occur when the storage service detects a network error when the client makes a storage request.
trans-unit.target: These occur when the storage service detects a network error when the client makes a storage request.

trans-unit.source: The most common cause of this error is a client disconnecting before a timeout expires in the storage service.
trans-unit.target: The most common cause of this error is a client disconnecting before a timeout expires in the storage service.

trans-unit.source: You should investigate the code in your client to understand why and when the client disconnects from the storage service.
trans-unit.target: You should investigate the code in your client to understand why and when the client disconnects from the storage service.

trans-unit.source: You can also use Wireshark, Microsoft Message Analyzer, or Tcping to investigate network connectivity issues from the client.
trans-unit.target: You can also use Wireshark, Microsoft Message Analyzer, or Tcping to investigate network connectivity issues from the client.

trans-unit.source: These tools are described in the [Appendices].
trans-unit.target: These tools are described in the [Appendices].

trans-unit.source: The client is receiving HTTP 403 (Forbidden) messages
trans-unit.target: The client is receiving HTTP 403 (Forbidden) messages

trans-unit.source: If your client application is throwing HTTP 403 (Forbidden) errors, a likely cause is that the client is using an expired Shared Access Signature (SAS) when it sends a storage request (although other possible causes include clock skew, invalid keys, and empty headers).
trans-unit.target: If your client application is throwing HTTP 403 (Forbidden) errors, a likely cause is that the client is using an expired Shared Access Signature (SAS) when it sends a storage request (although other possible causes include clock skew, invalid keys, and empty headers).

trans-unit.source: If an expired SAS key is the cause, you will not see any entries in the server-side Storage Logging log data.
trans-unit.target: If an expired SAS key is the cause, you will not see any entries in the server-side Storage Logging log data.

trans-unit.source: Failing with The remote server returned an error: (403) Forbidden.
trans-unit.target: Failing with The remote server returned an error: (403) Forbidden.

trans-unit.source: In this scenario, you should investigate why the SAS token is expiring before the client sends the token to the server:
trans-unit.target: In this scenario, you should investigate why the SAS token is expiring before the client sends the token to the server:

trans-unit.source: Typically, you should not set a start time when you create a SAS for a client to use immediately.
trans-unit.target: Typically, you should not set a start time when you create a SAS for a client to use immediately.

trans-unit.source: If there are small clock differences between the host generating the SAS using the current time and the storage service, then it is possible for the storage service to receive a SAS that is not yet valid.
trans-unit.target: If there are small clock differences between the host generating the SAS using the current time and the storage service, then it is possible for the storage service to receive a SAS that is not yet valid.

trans-unit.source: You should not set a very short expiry time on a SAS.
trans-unit.target: You should not set a very short expiry time on a SAS.

trans-unit.source: Again, small clock differences between the host generating the SAS and the storage service can lead to a SAS apparently expiring earlier than anticipated.
trans-unit.target: Again, small clock differences between the host generating the SAS and the storage service can lead to a SAS apparently expiring earlier than anticipated.

trans-unit.source: Does the version parameter in the SAS key (for example **sv=2012-02-12**) match the version of the Storage Client Library you are using.
trans-unit.target: Does the version parameter in the SAS key (for example **sv=2012-02-12**) match the version of the Storage Client Library you are using.

trans-unit.source: You should always use the latest version of the Storage Client Library.
trans-unit.target: You should always use the latest version of the Storage Client Library.

trans-unit.source: For more information on SAS token versioning and dependencies on client library version see .
trans-unit.target: For more information on SAS token versioning and dependencies on client library version see .

trans-unit.source: If you regenerate your storage access keys (click **Manage Access Keys** on any page in your storage account in the Azure portal) this can invalidate any existing SAS tokens.
trans-unit.target: If you regenerate your storage access keys (click **Manage Access Keys** on any page in your storage account in the Azure portal) this can invalidate any existing SAS tokens.

trans-unit.source: This may be an issue if you generate SAS tokens with a long expiry time for client applications to cache.
trans-unit.target: This may be an issue if you generate SAS tokens with a long expiry time for client applications to cache.

trans-unit.source: If you are using the Storage Client Library to generate SAS tokens, then it is easy to build a valid token.
trans-unit.target: If you are using the Storage Client Library to generate SAS tokens, then it is easy to build a valid token.

trans-unit.source: However, if you are using the Storage REST API and constructing the SAS tokens by hand you should carefully read the topic Delegating Access with a Shared Access Signature on MSDN.
trans-unit.target: However, if you are using the Storage REST API and constructing the SAS tokens by hand you should carefully read the topic Delegating Access with a Shared Access Signature on MSDN.

trans-unit.source: The client is receiving HTTP 404 (Not found) messages
trans-unit.target: The client is receiving HTTP 404 (Not found) messages

trans-unit.source: If the client application receives an HTTP 404 (Not found) message from the server, this implies that the object the client was attempting to use (such as an entity, table, blob, container, or queue) does not exist in the storage service.
trans-unit.target: If the client application receives an HTTP 404 (Not found) message from the server, this implies that the object the client was attempting to use (such as an entity, table, blob, container, or queue) does not exist in the storage service.

trans-unit.source: There are a number of possible reasons for this, such as:
trans-unit.target: There are a number of possible reasons for this, such as:

trans-unit.source: [The client or another process previously deleted the object]
trans-unit.target: [The client or another process previously deleted the object]

trans-unit.source: [A Shared Access Signature (SAS) authorization issue]
trans-unit.target: [A Shared Access Signature (SAS) authorization issue]

trans-unit.source: [Client-side JavaScript code does not have permission to access the object]
trans-unit.target: [Client-side JavaScript code does not have permission to access the object]

trans-unit.source: [Network failure]
trans-unit.target: [Network failure]

trans-unit.source: The client or another process previously deleted the object
trans-unit.target: The client or another process previously deleted the object

trans-unit.source: In scenarios where the client is attempting to read, update, or delete data in a storage service it is usually easy to identify in the server-side logs a previous operation that deleted the object in question from the storage service.
trans-unit.target: In scenarios where the client is attempting to read, update, or delete data in a storage service it is usually easy to identify in the server-side logs a previous operation that deleted the object in question from the storage service.

trans-unit.source: Very often, the log data shows that another user or process deleted the object.
trans-unit.target: Very often, the log data shows that another user or process deleted the object.

trans-unit.source: In the server-side Storage Logging log, the operation-type and requested-object-key columns show when a client deleted an object.
trans-unit.target: In the server-side Storage Logging log, the operation-type and requested-object-key columns show when a client deleted an object.

trans-unit.source: In the scenario where a client is attempting to insert an object, it may not be immediately obvious why this results in an HTTP 404 (Not found) response given that the client is creating a new object.
trans-unit.target: In the scenario where a client is attempting to insert an object, it may not be immediately obvious why this results in an HTTP 404 (Not found) response given that the client is creating a new object.

trans-unit.source: However, if the client is creating a blob it must be able to find the blob container, if the client is creating a message it must be able to find a queue, and if the client is adding a row it must be able to find the table.
trans-unit.target: However, if the client is creating a blob it must be able to find the blob container, if the client is creating a message it must be able to find a queue, and if the client is adding a row it must be able to find the table.

trans-unit.source: You can use the client-side log from the Storage Client Library to gain a more detailed understanding of when the client sends specific requests to the storage service.
trans-unit.target: You can use the client-side log from the Storage Client Library to gain a more detailed understanding of when the client sends specific requests to the storage service.

trans-unit.target: A Shared Access Signature (SAS) authorization issue

trans-unit.source: If the client application attempts to use a SAS key that does not include the necessary permissions for the operation, the storage service returns an HTTP 404 (Not found) message to the client.
trans-unit.target: If the client application attempts to use a SAS key that does not include the necessary permissions for the operation, the storage service returns an HTTP 404 (Not found) message to the client.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] You can use the F12 Developer Tools in Internet Explorer to trace the messages exchanged between the browser and the storage service when you are troubleshooting client-side JavaScript issues.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] You can use the F12 Developer Tools in Internet Explorer to trace the messages exchanged between the browser and the storage service when you are troubleshooting client-side JavaScript issues.

trans-unit.source: These errors occur because the web browser implements the same-origin policy security restriction that prevents a web page from calling an API in a different domain from the domain the page comes from.
trans-unit.target: These errors occur because the web browser implements the same-origin policy security restriction that prevents a web page from calling an API in a different domain from the domain the page comes from.

trans-unit.source: To work around the JavaScript issue, you can configure Cross Origin Resource Sharing (CORS) for the storage service the client is accessing.
trans-unit.target: To work around the JavaScript issue, you can configure Cross Origin Resource Sharing (CORS) for the storage service the client is accessing.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS) Support for Azure Storage Services on MSDN.

trans-unit.source: Network Failure
trans-unit.target: Network Failure

trans-unit.source: In some circumstances, lost network packets can lead to the storage service returning HTTP 404 messages to the client.
trans-unit.target: In some circumstances, lost network packets can lead to the storage service returning HTTP 404 messages to the client.

trans-unit.source: For example, when your client application is deleting an entity from the table service you see the client throw a storage exception reporting an "HTTP 404 (Not Found)" status message from the table service.
trans-unit.target: For example, when your client application is deleting an entity from the table service you see the client throw a storage exception reporting an "HTTP 404 (Not Found)" status message from the table service.

trans-unit.source: When you investigate the table in the table storage service, you see that the service did delete the entity as requested.
trans-unit.target: When you investigate the table in the table storage service, you see that the service did delete the entity as requested.

trans-unit.source: The exception details in the client include the request id (7e84f12d…) assigned by the table service for the request: you can use this information to locate the request details in the server-side storage logs by searching in the **request-id-header** column in the log file.
trans-unit.target: The exception details in the client include the request id (7e84f12d…) assigned by the table service for the request: you can use this information to locate the request details in the server-side storage logs by searching in the **request-id-header** column in the log file.

trans-unit.source: You could also use the metrics to identify when failures such as this occur and then search the log files based on the time the metrics recorded this error.
trans-unit.target: You could also use the metrics to identify when failures such as this occur and then search the log files based on the time the metrics recorded this error.

trans-unit.source: This log entry shows that the delete failed with an "HTTP (404) Client Other Error" status message.
trans-unit.target: This log entry shows that the delete failed with an "HTTP (404) Client Other Error" status message.

trans-unit.source: The same log entry also includes the request id generated by the client in the **client-request-id** column (813ea74f…).
trans-unit.target: The same log entry also includes the request id generated by the client in the **client-request-id** column (813ea74f…).

trans-unit.source: The server-side log also includes another entry with the same **client-request-id** value (813ea74f…) for a successful delete operation for the same entity, and from the same client.
trans-unit.target: The server-side log also includes another entry with the same **client-request-id** value (813ea74f…) for a successful delete operation for the same entity, and from the same client.

trans-unit.source: This successful delete operation took place very shortly before the failed delete request.
trans-unit.target: This successful delete operation took place very shortly before the failed delete request.

trans-unit.source: The most likely cause of this scenario is that the client sent a delete request for the entity to the table service, which succeeded, but did not receive an acknowledgement from the server (perhaps due to a temporary network issue).
trans-unit.target: The most likely cause of this scenario is that the client sent a delete request for the entity to the table service, which succeeded, but did not receive an acknowledgement from the server (perhaps due to a temporary network issue).

trans-unit.source: The client then automatically retried the operation (using the same **client-request-id**), and this retry failed because the entity had already been deleted.
trans-unit.target: The client then automatically retried the operation (using the same **client-request-id**), and this retry failed because the entity had already been deleted.

trans-unit.source: If this problem occurs frequently, you should investigate why the client is failing to receive acknowledgements from the table service.
trans-unit.target: If this problem occurs frequently, you should investigate why the client is failing to receive acknowledgements from the table service.

trans-unit.source: If the problem is intermittent, you should trap the "HTTP (404) Not Found" error and log it in the client, but allow the client to continue.
trans-unit.target: If the problem is intermittent, you should trap the "HTTP (404) Not Found" error and log it in the client, but allow the client to continue.

trans-unit.source: The code in the client application deletes and then immediately recreates a blob container using the same name: the **CreateIfNotExists** method (Client request ID bc881924-…) eventually fails with the HTTP 409 (Conflict) error.
trans-unit.target: The code in the client application deletes and then immediately recreates a blob container using the same name: the **CreateIfNotExists** method (Client request ID bc881924-…) eventually fails with the HTTP 409 (Conflict) error.

trans-unit.source: When a client deletes blob containers, tables, or queues there is a brief period before the name becomes available again.
trans-unit.target: When a client deletes blob containers, tables, or queues there is a brief period before the name becomes available again.

trans-unit.source: The client application should use unique container names whenever it creates new containers if the delete/recreate pattern is common.
trans-unit.target: The client application should use unique container names whenever it creates new containers if the delete/recreate pattern is common.

trans-unit.source: Metrics show low PercentSuccess or analytics log entries have operations with transaction status of ClientOtherErrors
trans-unit.target: Metrics show low PercentSuccess or analytics log entries have operations with transaction status of ClientOtherErrors

trans-unit.source: The **PercentSuccess** metric captures the percent of operations that were successful based on their HTTP Status Code.
trans-unit.target: The **PercentSuccess** metric captures the percent of operations that were successful based on their HTTP Status Code.

trans-unit.source: Operations with status codes of 2XX count as successful, whereas operations with status codes in 3XX, 4XX and 5XX ranges are counted as unsuccessful and lower the **PercentSucess** metric value.
trans-unit.target: Operations with status codes of 2XX count as successful, whereas operations with status codes in 3XX, 4XX and 5XX ranges are counted as unsuccessful and lower the **PercentSucess** metric value.

trans-unit.source: In the server-side storage log files, these operations are recorded with a transaction status of **ClientOtherErrors**.
trans-unit.target: In the server-side storage log files, these operations are recorded with a transaction status of **ClientOtherErrors**.

trans-unit.source: It is important to note that these operations have completed successfully and therefore do not affect other metrics such as availability.
trans-unit.target: It is important to note that these operations have completed successfully and therefore do not affect other metrics such as availability.

trans-unit.source: Some examples of operations that execute successfully but that can result in unsuccessful HTTP status codes include:
trans-unit.target: Some examples of operations that execute successfully but that can result in unsuccessful HTTP status codes include:

trans-unit.source: **ResourceNotFound** (Not Found 404), for example from a GET request to a blob that does not exist.
trans-unit.target: **ResourceNotFound** (Not Found 404), for example from a GET request to a blob that does not exist.

trans-unit.source: **ResouceAlreadyExists** (Conflict 409), for example from a **CreateIfNotExist** operation where the resource already exists.
trans-unit.target: **ResouceAlreadyExists** (Conflict 409), for example from a **CreateIfNotExist** operation where the resource already exists.

trans-unit.source: **ConditionNotMet** (Not Modified 304), for example from a conditional operation such as when a client sends an **ETag** value and an HTTP **If-None-Match** header to request an image only if it has been updated since the last operation.
trans-unit.target: **ConditionNotMet** (Not Modified 304), for example from a conditional operation such as when a client sends an **ETag** value and an HTTP **If-None-Match** header to request an image only if it has been updated since the last operation.

trans-unit.source: You can find a list of common REST API error codes that the storage services return on the page Common REST API Error Codes.
trans-unit.target: You can find a list of common REST API error codes that the storage services return on the page Common REST API Error Codes.

trans-unit.source: Capacity metrics show an unexpected increase in storage capacity usage
trans-unit.target: Capacity metrics show an unexpected increase in storage capacity usage

trans-unit.source: If you see sudden, unexpected changes in capacity usage in your storage account, you can investigate the reasons by first looking at your availability metrics; for example, an increase in the number of failed delete requests might lead to an increase in the amount of blob storage you are using as application specific cleanup operations you might have expected to be freeing up space may not be working as expected (for example, because the SAS tokens used for freeing up space have expired).
trans-unit.target: If you see sudden, unexpected changes in capacity usage in your storage account, you can investigate the reasons by first looking at your availability metrics; for example, an increase in the number of failed delete requests might lead to an increase in the amount of blob storage you are using as application specific cleanup operations you might have expected to be freeing up space may not be working as expected (for example, because the SAS tokens used for freeing up space have expired).

trans-unit.source: You are experiencing unexpected reboots of Virtual Machines that have a large number of attached VHDs
trans-unit.target: You are experiencing unexpected reboots of Virtual Machines that have a large number of attached VHDs

trans-unit.source: If a Virtual Machine (VM) has a large number of attached VHDs that are in the same storage account, you could exceed the scalability targets for an individual storage account causing the VM to fail.
trans-unit.target: If a Virtual Machine (VM) has a large number of attached VHDs that are in the same storage account, you could exceed the scalability targets for an individual storage account causing the VM to fail.

trans-unit.source: You should check the minute metrics for the storage account (**TotalRequests**/**TotalIngress**/**TotalEgress**) for spikes that exceed the scalability targets for a storage account.
trans-unit.target: You should check the minute metrics for the storage account (**TotalRequests**/**TotalIngress**/**TotalEgress**) for spikes that exceed the scalability targets for a storage account.

trans-unit.source: See the section "[Metrics show an increase in PercentThrottlingError]" for assistance in determining if throttling has occurred on your storage account.
trans-unit.target: See the section "[Metrics show an increase in PercentThrottlingError]" for assistance in determining if throttling has occurred on your storage account.

trans-unit.source: In general, each individual input or output operation on a VHD from a Virtual Machine translates to **Get Page** or **Put Page** operations on the underlying page blob.
trans-unit.target: In general, each individual input or output operation on a VHD from a Virtual Machine translates to **Get Page** or **Put Page** operations on the underlying page blob.

trans-unit.source: Therefore, you can use the estimated IOPS for your environment to tune how many VHDs you can have in a single storage account based on the specific behavior of your application.
trans-unit.target: Therefore, you can use the estimated IOPS for your environment to tune how many VHDs you can have in a single storage account based on the specific behavior of your application.

trans-unit.source: We do not recommend having more than 40 disks in a single storage account.
trans-unit.target: We do not recommend having more than 40 disks in a single storage account.

trans-unit.source: See Azure Storage Scalability and Performance Targets for details of the current scalability targets for storage accounts, in particular the total request rate and total bandwidth for the type of storage account you are using.
trans-unit.target: See Azure Storage Scalability and Performance Targets for details of the current scalability targets for storage accounts, in particular the total request rate and total bandwidth for the type of storage account you are using.

trans-unit.source: If you are exceeding the scalability targets for your storage account, you should place your VHDs in multiple different storage accounts to reduce the activity in each individual account.
trans-unit.target: If you are exceeding the scalability targets for your storage account, you should place your VHDs in multiple different storage accounts to reduce the activity in each individual account.

trans-unit.source: Your issue arises from using the storage emulator for development or test
trans-unit.target: Your issue arises from using the storage emulator for development or test

trans-unit.source: You typically use the storage emulator during development and test to avoid the requirement for an Azure storage account.
trans-unit.target: You typically use the storage emulator during development and test to avoid the requirement for an Azure storage account.

trans-unit.source: The common issues that can occur when you are using the storage emulator are:
trans-unit.target: The common issues that can occur when you are using the storage emulator are:

trans-unit.source: [Feature "X" is not working in the storage emulator]
trans-unit.target: [Feature "X" is not working in the storage emulator]

trans-unit.source: [Error "The value for one of the HTTP headers is not in the correct format" when using the storage emulator]
trans-unit.target: [Error "The value for one of the HTTP headers is not in the correct format" when using the storage emulator]

trans-unit.source: [Running the storage emulator requires administrative privileges]
trans-unit.target: [Running the storage emulator requires administrative privileges]

trans-unit.source: Feature "X" is not working in the storage emulator
trans-unit.target: Feature "X" is not working in the storage emulator

trans-unit.source: The storage emulator does not support all of the features of the Azure storage services such as the file service.
trans-unit.target: The storage emulator does not support all of the features of the Azure storage services such as the file service.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see Differences Between the Storage Emulator and Azure Storage Services on MSDN.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see Differences Between the Storage Emulator and Azure Storage Services on MSDN.

trans-unit.source: For those features that the storage emulator does not support, use the Azure storage service in the cloud.
trans-unit.target: For those features that the storage emulator does not support, use the Azure storage service in the cloud.

trans-unit.source: Error "The value for one of the HTTP headers is not in the correct format" when using the storage emulator
trans-unit.target: Error "The value for one of the HTTP headers is not in the correct format" when using the storage emulator

trans-unit.source: You are testing your application that use the Storage Client Library against the local storage emulator and method calls such as **CreateIfNotExists** fail with the error message "The value for one of the HTTP headers is not in the correct format."
trans-unit.target: You are testing your application that use the Storage Client Library against the local storage emulator and method calls such as **CreateIfNotExists** fail with the error message "The value for one of the HTTP headers is not in the correct format."

trans-unit.source: This indicates that the version of the storage emulator you are using does not support the version of the storage client library you are using.
trans-unit.target: This indicates that the version of the storage emulator you are using does not support the version of the storage client library you are using.

trans-unit.source: The Storage Client Library adds the header **x-ms-version** to all the requests it makes.
trans-unit.target: The Storage Client Library adds the header **x-ms-version** to all the requests it makes.

trans-unit.source: If the storage emulator does not recognize the value in the **x-ms-version** header, it rejects the request.
trans-unit.target: If the storage emulator does not recognize the value in the **x-ms-version** header, it rejects the request.

trans-unit.source: You can use the Storage Library Client logs to see the value of the **x-ms-version header** it is sending.
trans-unit.target: You can use the Storage Library Client logs to see the value of the **x-ms-version header** it is sending.

trans-unit.source: You can also see the value of the **x-ms-version header** if you use Fiddler to trace the requests from your client application.
trans-unit.target: You can also see the value of the **x-ms-version header** if you use Fiddler to trace the requests from your client application.

trans-unit.source: This scenario typically occurs if you install and use the latest version of the Storage Client Library without updating the storage emulator.
trans-unit.target: This scenario typically occurs if you install and use the latest version of the Storage Client Library without updating the storage emulator.

trans-unit.source: You should either install the latest version of the storage emulator, or use cloud storage instead of the emulator for development and test.
trans-unit.target: You should either install the latest version of the storage emulator, or use cloud storage instead of the emulator for development and test.

trans-unit.source: Running the storage emulator requires administrative privileges
trans-unit.target: Running the storage emulator requires administrative privileges

trans-unit.source: You are prompted for administrator credentials when you run the storage emulator.
trans-unit.target: You are prompted for administrator credentials when you run the storage emulator.

trans-unit.source: This only occurs when you are initializing the storage emulator for the first time.
trans-unit.target: This only occurs when you are initializing the storage emulator for the first time.

trans-unit.source: After you have initialized the storage emulator, you do not need administrative privileges to run it again.
trans-unit.target: After you have initialized the storage emulator, you do not need administrative privileges to run it again.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see Initialize the Storage Emulator by Using the Command-Line Tool on MSDN (you can also initialize the storage emulator in Visual Studio, which will also require administrative privileges).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see Initialize the Storage Emulator by Using the Command-Line Tool on MSDN (you can also initialize the storage emulator in Visual Studio, which will also require administrative privileges).

trans-unit.source: You are encountering problems installing the Azure SDK for .NET
trans-unit.target: You are encountering problems installing the Azure SDK for .NET

trans-unit.source: When you try to install the SDK, it fails trying to install the storage emulator on your local machine.
trans-unit.target: When you try to install the SDK, it fails trying to install the storage emulator on your local machine.

trans-unit.source: The installation log contains one of the following messages:
trans-unit.target: The installation log contains one of the following messages:

trans-unit.source: CAQuietExec: Error: Unable to access SQL instance
trans-unit.target: CAQuietExec: Error: Unable to access SQL instance

trans-unit.source: CAQuietExec: Error: Unable to create database
trans-unit.target: CAQuietExec: Error: Unable to create database

trans-unit.source: The cause is an issue with existing LocalDB installation.
trans-unit.target: The cause is an issue with existing LocalDB installation.

trans-unit.source: By default, the storage emulator uses LocalDB to persist data when it simulates the Azure storage services.
trans-unit.target: By default, the storage emulator uses LocalDB to persist data when it simulates the Azure storage services.

trans-unit.source: You can reset your LocalDB instance by running the following commands in a command-prompt window before trying to install the SDK.
trans-unit.target: You can reset your LocalDB instance by running the following commands in a command-prompt window before trying to install the SDK.

trans-unit.source: The **delete** command removes any old database files from previous installations of the storage emulator.
trans-unit.target: The **delete** command removes any old database files from previous installations of the storage emulator.

trans-unit.source: You have a different issue with a storage service
trans-unit.target: You have a different issue with a storage service

trans-unit.source: If the previous troubleshooting sections do not include the issue you are having with a storage service, you should adopt the following approach to diagnosing and troubleshooting your issue.
trans-unit.target: If the previous troubleshooting sections do not include the issue you are having with a storage service, you should adopt the following approach to diagnosing and troubleshooting your issue.

trans-unit.source: Check your metrics to see if there is any change from your expected base-line behavior.
trans-unit.target: Check your metrics to see if there is any change from your expected base-line behavior.

trans-unit.source: From the metrics, you may be able to determine whether the issue is transient or permanent, and which storage operations the issue is affecting.
trans-unit.target: From the metrics, you may be able to determine whether the issue is transient or permanent, and which storage operations the issue is affecting.

trans-unit.source: You can use the metrics information to help you search your server-side log data for more detailed information about any errors that are occurring.
trans-unit.target: You can use the metrics information to help you search your server-side log data for more detailed information about any errors that are occurring.

trans-unit.source: This information may help you troubleshoot and resolve the issue.
trans-unit.target: This information may help you troubleshoot and resolve the issue.

trans-unit.source: If the information in the server-side logs is not sufficient to troubleshoot the issue successfully, you can use the Storage Client Library client-side logs to investigate the behavior of your client application, and tools such as Fiddler, Wireshark, and Microsoft Message Analyzer to investigate your network.
trans-unit.target: If the information in the server-side logs is not sufficient to troubleshoot the issue successfully, you can use the Storage Client Library client-side logs to investigate the behavior of your client application, and tools such as Fiddler, Wireshark, and Microsoft Message Analyzer to investigate your network.

trans-unit.source: For more information about using Fiddler, see "[Appendix 1: Using Fiddler to capture HTTP and HTTPS traffic]."
trans-unit.target: For more information about using Fiddler, see "[Appendix 1: Using Fiddler to capture HTTP and HTTPS traffic]."

trans-unit.source: For more information about using Wireshark, see "[Appendix 2: Using Wireshark to capture network traffic]."
trans-unit.target: For more information about using Wireshark, see "[Appendix 2: Using Wireshark to capture network traffic]."

trans-unit.source: For more information about using Microsoft Message Analyzer, see "[Appendix 3: Using Microsoft Message Analyzer to capture network traffic]."
trans-unit.target: For more information about using Microsoft Message Analyzer, see "[Appendix 3: Using Microsoft Message Analyzer to capture network traffic]."

trans-unit.source: Appendices
trans-unit.target: Appendices

trans-unit.source: The appendices describe several tools that you may find useful when you are diagnosing and troubleshooting issues with Azure Storage (and other services).
trans-unit.target: The appendices describe several tools that you may find useful when you are diagnosing and troubleshooting issues with Azure Storage (and other services).

trans-unit.source: These tools are not part of Azure Storage and some are third-party products.
trans-unit.target: These tools are not part of Azure Storage and some are third-party products.

trans-unit.source: As such, the tools discussed in these appendices are not covered by any support agreement you may have with Microsoft Azure or Azure Storage, and therefore as part of your evaluation process you should examine the licensing and support options available from the providers of these tools.
trans-unit.target: As such, the tools discussed in these appendices are not covered by any support agreement you may have with Microsoft Azure or Azure Storage, and therefore as part of your evaluation process you should examine the licensing and support options available from the providers of these tools.

trans-unit.source: Appendix 1: Using Fiddler to capture HTTP and HTTPS traffic
trans-unit.target: Appendix 1: Using Fiddler to capture HTTP and HTTPS traffic

trans-unit.source: Fiddler is a useful tool for analyzing the HTTP and HTTPS traffic between your client application and the Azure storage service you are using.
trans-unit.target: Fiddler is a useful tool for analyzing the HTTP and HTTPS traffic between your client application and the Azure storage service you are using.

trans-unit.source: You can download Fiddler from http://www.telerik.com/fiddler.
trans-unit.target: You can download Fiddler from http://www.telerik.com/fiddler.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] Fiddler can decode HTTPS traffic; you should read the Fiddler documentation carefully to understand how it does this, and to understand the security implications.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] Fiddler can decode HTTPS traffic; you should read the Fiddler documentation carefully to understand how it does this, and to understand the security implications.

trans-unit.source: This appendix provides a brief walkthrough of how to configure Fiddler to capture traffic between the local machine where you have installed Fiddler and the Azure storage services.
trans-unit.target: This appendix provides a brief walkthrough of how to configure Fiddler to capture traffic between the local machine where you have installed Fiddler and the Azure storage services.

trans-unit.source: After you have launched Fiddler, it will begin capturing HTTP and HTTPS traffic on your local machine.
trans-unit.target: After you have launched Fiddler, it will begin capturing HTTP and HTTPS traffic on your local machine.

trans-unit.source: The following are some useful commands for controlling Fiddler:
trans-unit.target: The following are some useful commands for controlling Fiddler:

trans-unit.source: Stop and start capturing traffic.
trans-unit.target: Stop and start capturing traffic.

trans-unit.source: On the main menu, go to **File** and then click **Capture Traffic** to toggle capturing on and off.
trans-unit.target: On the main menu, go to **File** and then click **Capture Traffic** to toggle capturing on and off.

trans-unit.source: Save captured traffic data.
trans-unit.target: Save captured traffic data.

trans-unit.source: On the main menu, go to **File**, click **Save**, and then click **All Sessions**: this enables you to save the traffic in a Session Archive file.
trans-unit.target: On the main menu, go to **File**, click **Save**, and then click **All Sessions**: this enables you to save the traffic in a Session Archive file.

trans-unit.source: You can reload a Session Archive later for analysis, or send it if requested to Microsoft support.
trans-unit.target: You can reload a Session Archive later for analysis, or send it if requested to Microsoft support.

trans-unit.source: To limit the amount of traffic that Fiddler captures, you can use filters that you configure in the **Filters** tab.
trans-unit.target: To limit the amount of traffic that Fiddler captures, you can use filters that you configure in the **Filters** tab.

trans-unit.source: The following screenshot shows a filter that captures only traffic sent to the **contosoemaildist.table.core.windows.net** storage endpoint:
trans-unit.target: The following screenshot shows a filter that captures only traffic sent to the **contosoemaildist.table.core.windows.net** storage endpoint:

trans-unit.source: Appendix 2: Using Wireshark to capture network traffic
trans-unit.target: Appendix 2: Using Wireshark to capture network traffic

trans-unit.source: Wireshark is a network protocol analyzer that enables you to view detailed packet information for a wide range of network protocols.
trans-unit.target: Wireshark is a network protocol analyzer that enables you to view detailed packet information for a wide range of network protocols.

trans-unit.source: You can download Wireshark from http://www.wireshark.org/.
trans-unit.target: You can download Wireshark from http://www.wireshark.org/.

trans-unit.source: The following procedure shows you how to capture detailed packet information for traffic from the local machine where you installed Wireshark to the table service in your Azure storage account.
trans-unit.target: The following procedure shows you how to capture detailed packet information for traffic from the local machine where you installed Wireshark to the table service in your Azure storage account.

trans-unit.source: Launch Wireshark on your local machine.
trans-unit.target: Launch Wireshark on your local machine.

trans-unit.source: In the **Start** section, select the local network interface or interfaces that are connected to the internet.
trans-unit.target: In the **Start** section, select the local network interface or interfaces that are connected to the internet.

trans-unit.source: Click **Capture Options**.
trans-unit.target: Click **Capture Options**.

trans-unit.source: Add a filter to the **Capture Filter** textbox.
trans-unit.target: Add a filter to the **Capture Filter** textbox.

trans-unit.source: For example, **host contosoemaildist.table.core.windows.net** will configure Wireshark to capture only packets sent to or from the table service endpoint in the **contosoemaildist** storage account.
trans-unit.target: For example, **host contosoemaildist.table.core.windows.net** will configure Wireshark to capture only packets sent to or from the table service endpoint in the **contosoemaildist** storage account.

trans-unit.source: For a complete list of Capture Filters see http://wiki.wireshark.org/CaptureFilters.
trans-unit.target: For a complete list of Capture Filters see http://wiki.wireshark.org/CaptureFilters.

trans-unit.source: Click **Start**.
trans-unit.target: Click **Start**.

trans-unit.source: Wireshark will now capture all the packets send to or from the table service endpoint as you use your client application on your local machine.
trans-unit.target: Wireshark will now capture all the packets send to or from the table service endpoint as you use your client application on your local machine.

trans-unit.source: When you have finished, on the main menu click **Capture** and then **Stop**.
trans-unit.target: When you have finished, on the main menu click **Capture** and then **Stop**.

trans-unit.source: To save the captured data in a Wireshark Capture File, on the main menu click **File** and then **Save**.
trans-unit.target: To save the captured data in a Wireshark Capture File, on the main menu click **File** and then **Save**.

trans-unit.source: WireShark will highlight any errors that exist in the **packetlist** window.
trans-unit.target: WireShark will highlight any errors that exist in the **packetlist** window.

trans-unit.source: You can also use the **Expert Info** window (click **Analyze**, then **Expert Info**) to view a summary of errors and warnings.
trans-unit.target: You can also use the **Expert Info** window (click **Analyze**, then **Expert Info**) to view a summary of errors and warnings.

trans-unit.source: You can also chose to view the TCP data as the application layer sees it by right-clicking on the TCP data and selecting **Follow TCP Stream**.
trans-unit.target: You can also chose to view the TCP data as the application layer sees it by right-clicking on the TCP data and selecting **Follow TCP Stream**.

trans-unit.source: This is particularly useful if you captured your dump without a capture filter.
trans-unit.target: This is particularly useful if you captured your dump without a capture filter.

trans-unit.source: See here for more information.
trans-unit.target: See here for more information.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] For more information about using Wireshark, see the Wireshark Users Guide.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] For more information about using Wireshark, see the Wireshark Users Guide.

trans-unit.source: Appendix 3: Using Microsoft Message Analyzer to capture network traffic
trans-unit.target: Appendix 3: Using Microsoft Message Analyzer to capture network traffic

trans-unit.source: You can use Microsoft Message Analyzer to capture HTTP and HTTPS traffic in a similar way to Fiddler, and capture network traffic in a similar way to Wireshark.
trans-unit.target: You can use Microsoft Message Analyzer to capture HTTP and HTTPS traffic in a similar way to Fiddler, and capture network traffic in a similar way to Wireshark.

trans-unit.source: Configure a web tracing session using Microsoft Message Analyzer
trans-unit.target: Configure a web tracing session using Microsoft Message Analyzer

trans-unit.source: To configure a web tracing session for HTTP and HTTPS traffic using Microsoft Message Analyzer, run the Microsoft Message Analyzer application and then on the **File** menu, click **Capture/Trace**.
trans-unit.target: To configure a web tracing session for HTTP and HTTPS traffic using Microsoft Message Analyzer, run the Microsoft Message Analyzer application and then on the **File** menu, click **Capture/Trace**.

trans-unit.source: In the list of available trace scenarios, select **Web Proxy**.
trans-unit.target: In the list of available trace scenarios, select **Web Proxy**.

trans-unit.source: Then in the **Trace Scenario Configuration** panel, in the **HostnameFilter** textbox, add the names of your storage endpoints (you can look up these names in the Azure portal).
trans-unit.target: Then in the **Trace Scenario Configuration** panel, in the **HostnameFilter** textbox, add the names of your storage endpoints (you can look up these names in the Azure portal).

trans-unit.source: For example, if the name of your Azure storage account is **contosodata**, you should add the following to the **HostnameFilter** textbox:
trans-unit.target: For example, if the name of your Azure storage account is **contosodata**, you should add the following to the **HostnameFilter** textbox:

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] A space character separates the hostnames.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] A space character separates the hostnames.

trans-unit.source: When you are ready to start collecting trace data, click the **Start With** button.
trans-unit.target: When you are ready to start collecting trace data, click the **Start With** button.

trans-unit.source: For more information about the Microsoft Message Analyzer **Web Proxy** trace, see PEF-WebProxy Provider on TechNet.
trans-unit.target: For more information about the Microsoft Message Analyzer **Web Proxy** trace, see PEF-WebProxy Provider on TechNet.

trans-unit.source: The built-in **Web Proxy** trace in Microsoft Message Analyzer is based on Fiddler; it can capture client-side HTTPS traffic and display unencrypted HTTPS messages.
trans-unit.target: The built-in **Web Proxy** trace in Microsoft Message Analyzer is based on Fiddler; it can capture client-side HTTPS traffic and display unencrypted HTTPS messages.

trans-unit.source: The **Web Proxy** trace works by configuring a local proxy for all HTTP and HTTPS traffic that gives it access to unencrypted messages.
trans-unit.target: The **Web Proxy** trace works by configuring a local proxy for all HTTP and HTTPS traffic that gives it access to unencrypted messages.

trans-unit.source: Diagnosing network issues using Microsoft Message Analyzer
trans-unit.target: Diagnosing network issues using Microsoft Message Analyzer

trans-unit.source: In addition to using the Microsoft Message Analyzer **Web Proxy** trace to capture details of the HTTP/HTTPs traffic between the client application and the storage service, you can also use the built-in **Local Link Layer** trace to capture network packet information.
trans-unit.target: In addition to using the Microsoft Message Analyzer **Web Proxy** trace to capture details of the HTTP/HTTPs traffic between the client application and the storage service, you can also use the built-in **Local Link Layer** trace to capture network packet information.

trans-unit.source: This enables you to capture data similar to that which you can capture with Wireshark, and diagnose network issues such as dropped packets.
trans-unit.target: This enables you to capture data similar to that which you can capture with Wireshark, and diagnose network issues such as dropped packets.

trans-unit.source: The following screenshot shows an example **Local Link Layer** trace with some **informational** messages in the **DiagnosisTypes** column.
trans-unit.target: The following screenshot shows an example **Local Link Layer** trace with some **informational** messages in the **DiagnosisTypes** column.

trans-unit.source: Clicking on an icon in the **DiagnosisTypes** column shows the details of the message.
trans-unit.target: Clicking on an icon in the **DiagnosisTypes** column shows the details of the message.

trans-unit.source: In this example, the server retransmitted message #305 because it did not receive an acknowledgement from the client:
trans-unit.target: In this example, the server retransmitted message #305 because it did not receive an acknowledgement from the client:

trans-unit.source: When you create the trace session in Microsoft Message Analyzer, you can specify filters to reduce the amount of noise in the trace.
trans-unit.target: When you create the trace session in Microsoft Message Analyzer, you can specify filters to reduce the amount of noise in the trace.

trans-unit.source: On the **Capture / Trace** page where you define the trace, click on the **Configure** link next to **Microsoft-Windows-NDIS-PacketCapture**.
trans-unit.target: On the **Capture / Trace** page where you define the trace, click on the **Configure** link next to **Microsoft-Windows-NDIS-PacketCapture**.

trans-unit.source: The following screenshot shows a configuration that filters TCP traffic for the IP addresses of three storage services:
trans-unit.target: The following screenshot shows a configuration that filters TCP traffic for the IP addresses of three storage services:

trans-unit.source: For more information about the Microsoft Message Analyzer Local Link Layer trace, see PEF-NDIS-PacketCapture Provider on TechNet.
trans-unit.target: For more information about the Microsoft Message Analyzer Local Link Layer trace, see PEF-NDIS-PacketCapture Provider on TechNet.

trans-unit.source: Appendix 4: Using Excel to view metrics and log data
trans-unit.target: Appendix 4: Using Excel to view metrics and log data

trans-unit.source: Many tools enable you to download the Storage Metrics data from Azure table storage in a delimited format that makes it easy to load the data into Excel for viewing and analysis.
trans-unit.target: Many tools enable you to download the Storage Metrics data from Azure table storage in a delimited format that makes it easy to load the data into Excel for viewing and analysis.

trans-unit.source: Storage Logging data from Azure blob storage is already in a delimited format that you can load into Excel.
trans-unit.target: Storage Logging data from Azure blob storage is already in a delimited format that you can load into Excel.

trans-unit.source: However, you will need to add appropriate column headings based in the information at Storage Analytics Log Format and Storage Analytics Metrics Table Schema.
trans-unit.target: However, you will need to add appropriate column headings based in the information at Storage Analytics Log Format and Storage Analytics Metrics Table Schema.

trans-unit.source: To import your Storage Logging data into Excel after you download it from blob storage:
trans-unit.target: To import your Storage Logging data into Excel after you download it from blob storage:

trans-unit.source: On the **Data** menu, click **From Text**.
trans-unit.target: On the **Data** menu, click **From Text**.

trans-unit.source: Browse to the log file you want to view and click **Import**.
trans-unit.target: Browse to the log file you want to view and click **Import**.

trans-unit.source: On step 1 of the **Text Import Wizard**, select **Delimited**.
trans-unit.target: On step 1 of the **Text Import Wizard**, select **Delimited**.

trans-unit.source: On step 1 of the **Text Import Wizard**, select **Semicolon** as the only delimiter and choose double-quote as the **Text qualifier**.
trans-unit.target: On step 1 of the **Text Import Wizard**, select **Semicolon** as the only delimiter and choose double-quote as the **Text qualifier**.

trans-unit.source: Then click **Finish** and choose where to place the data in your workbook.
trans-unit.target: Then click **Finish** and choose where to place the data in your workbook.

trans-unit.source: Appendix 5: Monitoring with Application Insights for Visual Studio Online
trans-unit.target: Appendix 5: Monitoring with Application Insights for Visual Studio Online

trans-unit.source: You can also use the Application Insights feature for Visual Studio Online as part of your performance and availability monitoring.
trans-unit.target: You can also use the Application Insights feature for Visual Studio Online as part of your performance and availability monitoring.

trans-unit.source: This tool can:
trans-unit.target: This tool can:

trans-unit.source: Make sure your web service is available and responsive.
trans-unit.target: Make sure your web service is available and responsive.

trans-unit.source: Whether your app is a web site or a device app that uses a web service, it can test your URL every few minutes from locations around the world, and let you know if there’s a problem.
trans-unit.target: Whether your app is a web site or a device app that uses a web service, it can test your URL every few minutes from locations around the world, and let you know if there’s a problem.

trans-unit.source: Quickly diagnose any performance issues or exceptions in your web service.
trans-unit.target: Quickly diagnose any performance issues or exceptions in your web service.

trans-unit.source: Find out if CPU or other resources are being stretched, get stack traces from exceptions, and easily search through log traces.
trans-unit.target: Find out if CPU or other resources are being stretched, get stack traces from exceptions, and easily search through log traces.

trans-unit.source: If the app’s performance drops below acceptable limits, we can send you an email.
trans-unit.target: If the app’s performance drops below acceptable limits, we can send you an email.

trans-unit.source: You can monitor both .NET and Java web services.
trans-unit.target: You can monitor both .NET and Java web services.

trans-unit.source: At the time of writing Application Insights is in preview.
trans-unit.target: At the time of writing Application Insights is in preview.

trans-unit.source: You can find more information at Application Insights for Visual Studio Online on MSDN.
trans-unit.target: You can find more information at Application Insights for Visual Studio Online on MSDN.
